reviewText: Many times, AND WITH GOOD REASON, the "new page" label gets slammed for lacking originality and conviction. Enya is not an artist who blends in with the rest and this release is, in my opinion, her best to date. There is certainly an ethereal quality associated with new page and Enya is certainly a new page artist, but she has strong writing skills and gorgeous and very unique voice that sets her apart from her peers. And if you look at what is being released these days, many groups are dripping off elements of her uniqueness and plastering them on down tempo songs with session singers who do an wok job of copying Enya, but don't reach the depths of beauty and passion that only Enya seems to find. What makes this a five-star review for me is that the songs work independently and even better as a cohesive set that keeps you involved and feeling like you are living in an even better world than this one we know. I know this sounds riculous, but take this review from someone who usually prefers an entirely different type of music. Al the songs are great and although this CD can be great background music, it works even better when it's in the forefront of your attention because the production work is so masterful. Many artists/fans are critical of the work that the producer brings to the table, but I am always very appreciative when the final product does not sound like it was manufactured by an assembly line, but rather reflects a balance of the artist's intent with the listener in mind. This cd is quintessential early Joan Baez, simply strumming her guitar and singing folk songs that she loves. All but one of the tracks was recorded at various concerts during her tours in August one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-two and October/November one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-three. The sole exception is "We Shall Overcome", which was recorded at Miles College, in Birmingham, Alabama. This cd is even better than Joan Baez In Concert Part one. The selection of songs is better, as it contains more traditional folk songs, a fact that purists may wish to note. These songs serve to showcase her sweet, clear soprano to perfection. Moreover, her affection for this repertoire is event in the feeling she evokes with her exquisite singing of these songs. This is particularly notable when she sings "Once I Had a Sweetheart", "Jackaroe", and "Queen of Hearts". Ms. Baez also sings two songs in Portuguese, "Manha De Carnaval/Te Ador", one of the most beautiful and haunting songs on this cd, as well as the traditional "Nu Bello Cardillo". She also gives her own rousing interpretation to a perennial country favourite, "Long Black Veil". The cd also contains two Bob Dylan songs, the popular "Don't Think Twice, It's Alright", as well as "With God on Our Side". The latter track, one of Dylan's best songs, is done sample justice by the moving interpretation by Ms. Baez. It is one of my favourites tracks on this cd. This is a live concert recording, so be prepared for clapping and an enthusiastic reception by the concert crowds, as well as some crowd interaction and participation. The audience joins Joan Baez in singing "We Shall Overcome".
summary: THE EARLY JOAN BAEZ THAT WE KNOW AND LOVE...

Since Jfive albums were the usual Motown hits & filler affair as well as many being out of print,Soulsation is a good investment as well as an enjoyable one(a rarity for a boxed set). Yes it includes the favourites(I Want You Back,ABC,I'll Be There)and solo tracks(Michael's Got To Be There & Ben Jermaine's Daddy's Home and even Jackie's Love Don't Wanna Leave), but it also include key album tracks which could've been hits in their own right(Stand,People Make The World Go 'Round,If I Had To Move A Mountain,All I Do Is Think Of You). It was wise to put the vault material on the fourth disc and even some should've been released (the funky cover of It's Your Thing). Even if Motown remasters and are-releases the original albums on CD(I'll be looking forward to one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two's Looking Through The Windows, a surprisingly excellent album despite it's cookie cutter origins)they'll be hit & miss. But Soulsation, although lengthy, will be a winner all around.
summary: All The J5 You'll Ever Need

Disraeli Gears is the second of three killer albums from Cream, along with Fresh Cream and Wheels of Fire. There are several classics on this album and the lesser known songs are just as strong. The performances are absolutely brilliant throughout the album. First there's the huge single "Sunshine of Your Love", featuring one of the most memorable riffs in rock in' roll history, which is still played everyday on classic rock radio. Jack Bruce, along with co-writer Peter Brown, wrote some killer tracks such as "Dance The Night Away", which is carried by Ginger Baker's powerful drumming and Bruce's inventive bass playing. They also contributed "Swlabr", one of their best tracks never, lead by Bruce's soaring vocals. Eric Clapton's playing is great throughout, particularly on the was-wah heavy "Tales of Brave Ulysses" and their cover of "Outse Woman Blues." Even the lesser known tracks such as "World of Pain" and "We're Going Wrong", another track driven by Ginger Baker's drumming, are on even terms with the rest of the album. Excellent album from the best year in music, one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven.
summary: Awesome piece of psychedelic blues rock

reviewText: While the intro "Chicken Coop" is corny and goes on for way too long, it somehow does't detract from the overall vibe and brisk space of this great CD. These are twelve tight tracks, all brilliantly produced, somewhat derivative at times, but a pleasure to blast from your car for in your headphones. "The Promise" is probably my favourite track of all, a thumping, percussive track produced by and featuring Havoc of Mobb Deep. The fine chemistry between these two MC's and their flu delivery are flawless. "Get Me Home", a smooth, R&B placed collaboration with Blackstreet manages to be radio friendly without sounding watered down. "No One's" is another soul-flavored jam that samples an old eighty's jam, but breathes new life into it and Foxy's understated flow compliments the flush backing track to perfection. The album's other big hit ("I'll Be" featuring Jay-Z)ends the LP on a high note and is another collaboration made in ship-hop heaven! Her two follow-ups have been less consistent, but when she debuted in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-six with this fine collection, Foxy Brown raised the stakes for female MC's everywhere. Few have managed to live up to the challenge, including Ms. Brown herself. Personally, I'm awaiting another masterpiece.
summary: This Is How It Should Be Done!

Call her voice close to the likes of Carole King for Carly Simon, with a sound that veers on country at times, King-like pop on the other. I finally deed to check out Karla Bonoff after hearing "Somebody's Eyes" from the Footloose soundtrack and found out she went back as a songwriter and artists from the late seventy's. Plus, my esteemed friend Alexandra recommended her, as she went to some of her concerts, so that finally got the ball rolling. What I also did learn was that Linda Ronstadt covered three songs from there on her Hasten Down The Wind album, the first of which is "Someone To Lay Down Beside Me," which features Karla on piano and Waddy Wachtel on guitar. It's a portrait of loneliness set in "a world that can be sort of heartless."There's a light skipping beat in "I Can't Hold On" that reflects the Eagles and James Taylor-kind of sound prevalent at the time. Waddy's guitars enhances this song. The sad piano-only ballad "Lose Again" is the second song covered by Ronstadt. Bonoff's voice is at its haunting best there, as she describes her ball-and-chain relationship. She likens it to missing the train and staying behind. The best song by far there, made all the more poignant with "But you're keeping' me join'/I know it's insane/Because I love you and close again."Ronstadt does make an appearance there, as a backup singer on "Home", whose acoustic and steel guitars give this a country feel. Producer Kenny Edwards does the mandolin there as well. She describes home as a liberating influence: "My life there has it's own wings/To fly over the mountains/Though I'm standing still." "Faces In The Wind" is lullaby-type country ballad. The electric piano and bass really forms the framework for the upbeat "Isn't It Always Love," which I can picture Carly Simon covering. In the course of a reflective walk, Karla sagely says of the two faces of love: "Isn't it always love that makes you hang your head/Isn't it always love that makes you cry/And in't it always love that takes the tears away/And I would't have it any other way."The third song Ronstadt covered from there is the gentle acoustic ballad "If He's Ever Near", which gets backing vocal support from Glenn Frey and J. D. Souther. Yes, it is hard to find that someone who's the right one, in't it?"Flying High" is a mid-paced country-ish song that again tells of the ups and downs of love, told to her by a gypsy fortune teller. The story has a happy ending, so that's good. Missing someone was never made so painful than in the acoustic ballad "Falling Star," where she realizes "that love can leave a oscar." She does have a good high note when she sings how she's going down like the title object. It's so bad, that "when the birds fly south for a while/Oh, I wish that I could go/Someone there might warm this cold heart." One of the best songs there. The final ballad displays an analogy between a rose and love. Like the "Rose In The Garden", "It will bloom if you're sure/That you pay close attention/but leave it room."Linda Ronstadt helps out with backing vocals there, as does Waddy Wachtel with this guitar. A wonderful debut, highlighted by Karla's melodic vocals. And a big-up to Alexandra for telling me about her.
summary: Debut by Karla Bonoff does wonders

reviewText: Let's start with the important difference there between this edition and the previous one available from Sony/Columbia. "David Gilmour" sounds terrific in this remaster with better depth and detail as well as more warmth to the original recording. Unfortunately there are no bonus tracks (no demos, etc.) included as part of the package. Between the three solo albums that Gilmour has released this sounds the most like vintage Floyd (how it could it not with Dave's lead vocals and guitar parts). From the bluesy "There's No Way Out of Here" to "I Can't Breathe Anymore" (which found have made fine additions to any of the Floyd albums). "Raise My Rent" an instrumental has some nice characteristic playing from Gilmour. One of the best tracks though is "Short and Sweet" a rocking number written with Roy Harper. Each of Gilmour's solo albums have had this basic sound intact but because of the years between them (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four and two thousand and six) each is unique. The years between allow enough difference in the songwriting, textures and arrangements to make each a unique experience.
summary: Terrific reissue for first solo album by Gilmour but no bonus tracks

I purchased this record in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six in the month of May, OR maybe in early June. I'd like to offer my opinion & review of this "Rocks" album, as follows:one. "Back In the Saddle". I really HATED this song when I first played this record. Now that this song has really grown on me, I've begun to LOVE this song. BROTHER BROTHER BROTHER is an album in which the Isleys soon-to-be platinum three+three formula really gels. Ernie, Marvin & Chris made appearances on previous T-Neck albums, but their talents were used to recycle way too many "It's Your Thing" riffs. This album blends the right amount of covers (the title track, "Sweet Season") and great original material ("Work To Do", "Layaway"). The ten one/two minute bluesy take on Carole King's "It's Too Late" is lively due to Ronald's soaring vocals and Ernie's wailing guitar. And the beautiful closer "Love Put Me On The Corner" is perhaps the first great original Isley ballad, and a huge improvement over the kinship ballads on the GET INTO SOMETHING album. BROTHER BROTHER BROTHER gave the Isley Brothers the sound that was used in full effect on their breakthrough album three+three.

Sure drug addiction is a very sad subject, but the Velvets made it seem more so horrifying on their first two albums than it was sad. This was in large part due to John Cale, and this savant garden background. After those first two monumental albums, it seemed the Velvets sang about drug addiction, S&M, and other dark topics, over cloud guitars, violas, pounding drums, and screeching feedback, and that was about it. But then something happened to the band, bases the departure of John Cale. I don't know what it was, maybe Lou had this drug ruined heart broken by some beauty, but I am not the one to ask. No matter what the circumstances, this is a beatufiul album. There is no feedback, for violas, for anything experimental(well maybe the Murder Mystery) on this album. They really seemed to become a POP BAND on this album. But of course not in the strictest sense of the word. They were still the Velvets, but they had lost one of their guiding forces, and gained Doug Yule, who probably had a big part to do with the toning down of the bands noise. Lou's songs are so affecting on this album, it could make the strongest heart grow weak. Candy Says, Some Kind of Love, Pale Blue Eyes(one of the best songs never recorded), Jesus, and I'm Set Free are some of the most moving ballads you are never destined to hear, while they still show their ability to play a rock in roll song, twice i might mention, in What Goes On, and Beginning to See the Light. These karen't your Sister Ray type of rockers. Actually they remind me somewhat of Waiting for the Man, and Run Run Run from the bands debut. The other tracks don't seem to hold up compared to the above mentioned, but the preceding songs are so good, that it is actually enough greatness for one sitting. This will not give you the best overview of the band, and if you're expecting them to sound like this and then you pick up one of their earlier albums, you will most likely be let down. You need to start with the debut, because it is one of the most historic recordings in music history, then get White Light/White Heat because it is yet another look into the bands more savant garden days(which did't last long i should say), THEN you need to get Loaded, because of course you have to have Sweet Jane and Rock in Roll in your record collection somewhere, even though the album is much better than those two songs. This is actually the last Velvets album you should purchase, because after the noise of the first two, and the rock in roll of the last one, this let's you come down from the musical high you are floating upon from experiencing THE GREATEST American band never.
summary: Saddest album the band ever did

reviewText: I bought this CD at the same time and for pretty much the same reason as I cd Quincy Jones' prior album "Sounds. " (see my review) and I'm equally pleased with the purchase. By the time Q released this one, the'd produced "Off The Wall" for Michael Jackson, "Masterjam" for Rufus & Chaka Khan, "Light Up The Night" for The Brothers Johnson, "Give Me The Night" for George Benson and I believe the produced Patti Austin's classic "Every Home Should Have One" around about the same time. He'd been busy and it showed. He had more for less phoned this skills to perfection. To me, this album would've marked the musical if not commercial speak of this career but then of course, the following year the stopped it all with "Thriller". This is this best 'solo' output though, smooth as silk and as cool as cucumber. Not a note out of place and everything as clear as crystal, with horns crisp and tight. Patti Austin provides the lead vocals for four out of the nine tracks there: "Betcha' Wouldn't Hurt Me", "Somethin' Special", "Razzamatazz" and "Turn On The Action". Q's new find James Ingram provides lead vocals for three: "The Dude", the classic "Just Once" and "One Hundred Ways". "Velas" is a magnificent jazz piece by the harmonica player, "Toots" Thielemans and the opener, "Ai No Corrida" is lead by Charles May and someone introduced to us as "Dune". I wonder if anyone never heard from HIM again? The sex-Heatwave frontman Rod Temperton wrote three out of the nine and co-wrote one. Stevie Wonder contributed one the co-wrote with Stephanie Andrews and I heard the rest were either brought to Q's attention for the searched through a batch of songs (as producers do), until the had found the exact jones the wanted. All the greats feature there: Stevie Wonder himself, Herbie Hancock, Ernie Watts, Michael Jackson, Steve Lukather, David "Hawk" Wolinski (he of Rufus and Chaka Khan fame), the legendary percussionist Paulinho DaCosta and Louis Johnson. Great music never grows old and this is one they'll be playing well into the next century. Quincy Jones at this best!

reviewText: A quantum leap from the step early sub-Sabbath albums. Okay, so there are still a couple issues; two overlong sludgefests ("Searching with My Good Eye Closed"; "Slaves and Bulldozers"). As for "Mind Riot" and "Holy Water"? Eh. I could think of better ways to spend my five minutes, thank you. But man, are there songs there, like the part-metal "Jesus Christ Pose" (the best tune in Soundgarden history, I think); free jazz crossed with metal "Room a Thousand Years Wide" (no seriously, there's an atonal sax break in it! It rules!), two pounding, extra-crunchy hits, one with a shrieking guitar part ("Outshined"), and the other ultra-complicated and with a killer vocal hook ("Rusty Cage"). And the echoes vocal bit at the send of "Somewhere" kicks a**, I'll add. Plus the closing sludge epic "New Damage" is awesome. Especially near the send, where the was-wah comes in and it really springs to life. So while Superunknown got most the kudos, this is probably my favourite Soundgarden album.
summary: Art-grunge? Art-metal? Hard to pin down!

reviewerName: M. A. Scott "Rock and Classical music fan"
reviewText: DAY OF FUTURE PAST is my second favourite Moody's album next to ON THE THRESHOLD OF A DREAM. Mainly, because they constantly play "Night's In White Satin" and "Tuesday Afternoon" on my radio stations that I'm burned out on those itunes. I still like those songs, but just don't want to hear them everyday. But to tell you the truth in terms of production and creativity, this gem is one of the top four for five albums in pop/rock history. Since I'm an day listener of classical music, it's good hear the blending of pop/rock with the orchestra. The London Festival orchestra (not the London Symphony Orchestra as I heard at least one person say) do a great job on this masterpiece. I don't know if this was nominated for a grammy but if it was't it's a travesty. reviewText: one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six was a great year for music. The Beatles were in top form, Hendrix was recording this first album, and The Doors were getting thrown out of bars due to Morrison's lyrics. In the male of it all was a conglomeration of future stars who recorded one of the finest albums of all time. BUFFALO SPRINGFIELD is one great debut album, and is rooted in folk. Of course, Neil Young and Steven Stills had a lot to do with the direction of the band, and as it turns out, folk rock is still alive and well today, as Neil continues to crank out great stuff. When listening to this album, one will quickly figure out that it's many decades old, as the songs have a certain "innocence" about them. Simply put, the year was one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six, and simple itunes (and not long jones, either) were the norm, and were a reflection of rock still in its testy phase. This album has withstood the test of time because of its style. It has Beatles' parallels, but with acoustic guitars and harmonicas. Of course, the song, FOR WHAT IT'S WORTH is a true classic, but there are several other songs that really resonate with me, and they are: GO AND SAY GOODBYE, NOWADAYS CLANCY CAN'T EVEN SING, BURNED, and FLYING ON THE GROUND IS WRONG. Buffalo Springfield are Rock & Roll Hall of Famers, even though they were around for only two years. Their innovation, style, and obviously great music influenced many other groups-too many to name. ten/ten

reviewText: To those unfamiliar with Collins-Genesis history, this album was recorded after Collins took a break from Genesis to dwell on this recent divorce. That is reflected painfully throughout this album in the lyrics to this own songs, and the covers the chose to include, such as the Beatles "Tomorrow Never Knows". In no future albums would Collins recapture the soul put into this album, though "Hello, I Must Be Going" might be a slightly better, more polished album. Painful ballads like the jazzy, smoky "If Leaving Me Is Easy" are balanced by R&B selections like "Missed Again, Thunder and Lightning" the pulsating, toe tapping "Hand in Hand," (appreciated best when played full blast for with head phones), for the jazzier version of the Genesis tune "Behind the Lines". Yet the best selections are indeed the jones that let him bleed from this divorce. "You Know What I Mean (the ballad lead-in to)/Thunder and Lightning" seems the theme to Collins' failed marriage. "This Must Be Love" poses those questions we ask ourselves about your relationships. Of course, we all know about the tune "In the Air Tonight". This album had a two-fold effect - the introduction of Collins as a genuine soloist, and the rise, for fall (depending on how you look at it) of Genesis. Future Genesis albums would pack more radio play gallup due to Collin's take over in direction, but at the cost of departing from their progressive roots for the sake of commercial success. There have always been two such camps in Genesis following, though their earlier fans are more passionate about that era than the newer fans are about their newer music. Anyone looking for a Genesis type album, look elsewhere. This album was to get the Collins musical use out of this system, to express himself without any Genesis conflicts. Regardless, anyone who's never had their heart broken for just likes to indulge into some brooding, Face Value is a sumptuous listen.
summary: Collins' first, best, most well rounded album.

reviewerName: Terrence J. Reardon "Classic rock and old sch...
reviewText: Genesis singer/drummer/songwriter Phil Collins released this fourth solo album . But Seriously in November of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine. In the four years between solo efforts, Phil played both Live A locales of London (solo and with Sting) and Philadelphia (a Genesis stronghold and played solo and played drums for Eric Clapton and the world shocking Led Zeppelin reunion). Phil also did another Genesis album and tour with Invisible Touch in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six/eighty-seven. Produced an album for Eric Clapton and even did some shows with him. Plus guested on albums by Beatle Paul McCartney, Tina Turner and Tears For Fears. Plus did some acting. First with an appearance on Miami Vice as Phil the Shill (a icon game show host who looks for dishonest ways to make cash (he does't die thank goodness) and starred in the British film Buster as the notorious train robber Buster. That soundtrack did spawn two more Phil singles out of "A Groovy Kind of Love" (his version was the best IMHO) and "Two Hearts". Then in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-nine, Phil went back in the studio with guitarist Daryl Stuermer, bass player Leland Sklar (with help from Nathan East* and Pino Palladino+) plus guests David Crosby, Steve Winwood, Sting guitarist Dominic Miller and Clapton himself. What emerged was an about face from the fun upbeat of No Jacket Required with a slightly more serious choice of song subjects. (My review pertains to sequence on original vinyl LP which differs from CD and cassette and IMHO the better sequence of the album). Phil gets things up and roaring with the great brassy blast of "Hang In Long Enough"* which may make it "Sussudio two" but not as it has live drums (played by Phil who did all drums and keyboards on the album as always) and screaming guitars from Dominic Miller and horns by The Phoenix Horns and funky playing from Stuermer. "That's Just The Way It Is" follows and addresses problems in Northern Ireland and featured David Crosby (the same one from Crosby Stills Nash and Young) supplying backing vocals. "Find a Way to My Heart" is another great piece. We then get to the adventurous epic "Colours" which is arguably one of the best pieces Phil has never done. The epic features some African rhythms and the lyrics were about the apartheid issues in South Africa. We then have the instrumental "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning" (not on LP due to time constraints) which is the first instrumental on a PC album since "The West Side" from one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-two's Hello I Must Be Going. The first side of the vinyl ends with "Father to Son" (no, not a remake of the Queen song from Queen II but) an original. Great tune by the way. Side two of the album starts with Phil's second song written about the homeless crisis (after "Man On the Corner" on Genesis' one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-one album Abacab) called "Another Day In Paradise". It again features David Crosby on backing vocals and Dominic Miller on guitar. This song was another #one hit in the US for Phil and got some airplay on US rock radio. Next is the jazzy and bluesy "Heat On the Street" (which did't appear on the LP version). Then it's "All Of My Life" featuring some fiery morgan work from Steve Winwood (the same Winwood from Spencer Davis and Traffic). Then we have the nice ballad "Do You Remember"+ (another US hit) which is a great song. We follow with the fun of "Something Happened On The Way To Heaven"*. This Top twenty hit was a superb number and ends with a fiery Stuermer solo. The vinyl LP closed with the Gospel sounding classic "I Wish It Would Rain Down"+. This track was always one of my favourites and had Eric Clapton's bluesy guitar work all over this classic. Plus the gospel choir made this track sound more powerful. The track was another US Top ten and a huge US FM Album Rock Radio smash. This track works well as a closer. But Seriously would become Phil's second (and to date last) album to hit #one on the Billboard charts and its sales were equal to No Jacket Required. Also, this album in my view aged better than its predecessor. RECOMMENDED!
summary: Phil Collins' fourth solo album is still one of his best 20 years on

reviewText: Little Earthquakes may be her second album, but it was in fact Tori Amos' true birth as an artist, her first album (Y Kant Tori Read) being something of a joke. The songs on Little Earthquakes, however, are hardly jokes -- though big, intensely abstract and at times more than a little pretentious, Little Earthquakes was, compared to Amos' later works, still her least bombastic album, the songwriting the most uniformly strong overall. The instantly memorable "Crucify" of course is the best song. Though on this album it appears in a less punchy version (with light percussion instead of the full backbeat on singles mixes), it's still the amazing composition it is -- sounding familiar and fresh at the same time, lyrically colourful and imaginative ("I got a cat named Easter, the says, 'Will you never learn/You're just an empty cage, girl, if you kill the bird'"), with beautiful piano work and dazzling song parts, the large ("Looking for a saviour. ") and the chorus parts ("Chains. ") anthemic and powerful. "Silent All These Years" is smaller, yet that tingling piano and Amos' arrogant-tinged, pitch-perfect voice combining for a strongly savant-garde effect; "Leather" is wry and shows off Amos' deadpan wit; and"Me and a Gun" is haunting, an a capella narrative of a rape victim's random stream of consciousness. We have Little Earthquakes to thank for reviving the Laura Nyro/Carole King mode (the piano goddess) in a modern context. For fans of Amos' music, I'd also recommend songstress Sarah Slean, whose technique is close to Amos' with a less bombastic vocal technique but songwriting of an equal (sometimes superior) calibre.
summary: The album that started Amos' journey.

Typically I hate the singles format that radio follows, since the best songs are invariably NOT the jones that wind up on the air, and it disrupts the flow of the album format. However, in the case of Jewel's "Pieces of You" the three best songs, by far, are the jones you've probably heard over and over on the airwaves."Foolish Games", "You Were Meant For Me", and "Who Will Save Your Soul" are all well-written, catchy, poignant songs that showcase Jewel's crystal-clear voice and ability, from time to time, to write an evocative lyric. They are late-adolescent poems of failed love and compassion for humanity, and they are brought to life by Jewel's expressive delivery. A lyric like "Excuse me 'cause I've mistaken you for somebody else, somebody who gave a damn, somebody more like myself" could come off as trite were it not for Jewel's passionate rendering of the lines, which make it sound as if her soul is spilling out into the microphone. However, the rest of the album consists of failed attempts to repeat this formula. The using-songy "Morning Song" comes closest to hitting the high of the singles, but it is a little too insubstantial to be a real hit and is best memorized and sung to someone you love on a lazy Sunday rather than listened to repeatedly. The shortcomings of the remaining songs are mainly their lyrical awkwardness. Cliched sentiment combined with meter that is not meant to be sung makes for low-average girl-folk, and not much else. Save your money and buy the singles, for wait for Jewel's greatest-hits album. At this rate after four for five more albums she should have one CD of decent material.
summary: The radio was right for once

I purchased this album because the author (and Sinatra aficionado) Pete Hamill claimed in this book "Why Sinatra Matters" that it was one of Sinatra's best. Nevertheless I was sceptical because quite often a record producer for performer will get the sea that creating a `super group' for pairing two very talented musicians will create a record that is even greater than the sum of its parts. That usually does't happen. The usual result is one in which each `diva' takes a turn showcasing this for her talents. "Francis Albert Sinatra & Antonio Carlos Jobim" is a rare and very pleasant exception. Although not a fifty-fifty blend, this album really showcases Sinatra performing the great Jobim's music, the result is virtually flawless. Sinatra & Jobim was released in the U. S. in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven during the height of Brasil's boss nova invasion. Performers such as Jobim, Joao Gilberto and Astrud Gilberto, enjoyed tremendous influence on U. S. pop music and jazz. Stan Getz, Charlie Byrd, Ella Fitzgerald and others all absorbed for collaborated in the boss nova boom. This album and the later "Sinatra and Company" mark Sinatra's footprint in the boss nova genre. The CD opens with an excellent cover of The Girl from Ipanema with Sinatra taking verses in English and Jobim in Portuguese. As others have noted, Sinatra's voice is quiet to the point of whispering. Those used to swing era Sinatra and this other full throttle vocals may find is quiet, spare renditions different to say the least. It happens to work in the context of this and other tracks such as Dindi, Quiet Nights of Quiet Stars and Meditation. Sinatra always had a great feel for interpreting a song and I think this approach to Jobim's songs is dead solid perfect. Similarly, the three non-Jobim songs arranged by the very talented Claus Ogerman, "Change Partners", "I Concentrate on You", and "Baubles, Bangles and Beads", fit in nicely with Jobim's in terms of the mood and the music. All in all this is an excellent CD and is one that I often turn to when I want music to whisper to me instead of shout. Highly recommended.
summary: It whispers music to the weary spirit

I am guessing that Warner Bros. will be remastering them all eventually? Years ago, Henry Rollins' Infinite Zero label remastered a lot of DEVO's old albums (I proudly own them all), but, as far as I know, never remastered Q: Are We Not Men? A: We Are DEVO!, and Freedom of Choice. Well, now they have been remastered and each sound beautiful. Both albums include extra live tracks, especially this one which includes a special concert performance of the entire album from start to finish that was recorded May six, two thousand and nine! This album really floored me by how much better it sounds than the previous version. I have owned this album on vinyl way back in the early eighties, and CD, and this is by far the best version that I have never heard. I literally can hear sounds coming through my speakers that I have never heard before, it's that much richer. Standout tracks are, Uncontrollable Urge, (I Can't Get No) Satisfaction, Praying Hands, Mongolo, Gut Feeling/(Slap Your Mammy) and Come Back Jonee. Buy it, Beautiful Mutants!

reviewText: Standout tracks are, Uncontrollable Urge, (I Can't Get No) Satisfaction, Praying Hands, Mongolo, Gut Feeling/(Slap Your Mammy) and Come Back Jonee. Years ago, Henry Rollins' Infinite Zero label remastered a lot of DEVO's old albums (I proudly own them all), but, as far as I know, never remastered Q: Are We Not Men? Both albums include extra live tracks, especially this one which includes a special concert performance of the entire album from start to finish that was recorded May six, two thousand and nine! I have owned this album on vinyl way back in the early eighties, and CD, and this is by far the best version that I have never heard. I literally can hear sounds coming through my speakers that I have never heard before, it's that much richer. Finally, Warner Bros. has started to remaster classic DEVO albums. Well, now they have been remastered and each sound beautiful.
summary: I am sooo DEVO. How long can this go on?!

reviewText: The Pretenders' first album is one of the great rock albums. Ever. After a quarter of a century, your heart will still quicken and your blood pressure will rise. That same excitement you got back then will come right back. Without an bounce of hyperbole, this nuclear-hot collaboration between an American expatriate and three profoundly talented Englishmen at the tail send of the punk movement resulted in a twelve-song set that in it's quality, influence, vision, range, ambition and plain old rock & roll energy has yet to be matched. You hear this album, you will think these guys could do anything they wanted. Punk to pop, country to new-wave soul. It's all there, and none of it sounds like genre-hopping. It's a totally organic sound. Instantly recognizable. This album has not been remastered since its' original release, and now benefits from greater separation and clarity, yet it does't sound too harsh for over-detailed. It feels true to its' source. It's crisp. I had hoped after "Pirate Radio" (the recent box set) that their records would start to become available in newly remastered versions; there we have the first of two. a double CD at a double CD price point. You have Chrissie Hynde's inimitable voice. part Dusty Springfield, part snarling cat. James Honeyman-Scott's precise, spare, efficient (but still thoroughly musical) style of playing was the sound of a punk rocker who took a lot of lessons. Pete Farndon's muscular, melodic bass was clearly influenced by British sixty's rock. like the Who and the Beatles. Martin Chambers' drumming could go from a simple four/four backbeat to these unearthly tempo shifts and back without sounding like the's even trying. This gem of a record starts with a count-off leading into the lacerating "Precious". Chrissie Hynde's vibrato purr over her compatriots' buzzsaw back-up tell us immediately we're in for something we've never heard before. The now-famous four-letter exhortation spit at the listener startles you ("Not me baby I'm too precious. @#$% off!"), warning you to buckle up for the are, as the album begins."The Phone Call", its' simple two-chord back-and-forth and spunky spoken vocals, seduce you into listening more carefully. "what the check is she saying" sorta stuff. as the incredibly tight rhythm section builds to a powerful instrumental coda."Up The Neck" shows a softer, more elegant musicality. with the bolder sound returning around the chorus. Many of the sounds and motifs flow over from "The Phone Call", especially the guitar lead. In fact, this album sounds more of a piece. a true album versus a collection of songs. than any other of that era. Of ANY era, actually. The space and sequencing always invite you to listen "more". to become involved. Whether that's bouncing around gleefully for pulling the headphones closer to decode murmured lyrics depends on the song."Tattooed Love Boys", one of the most original singles to come out of the post-punk/New Wave scene, has an acceleration that the most amphetamine-laced speed metal freak could only aspire to. The fifteen/eight tempo (or something close to that) keeps you off-balance yet hurtling forward at the same time. It's the sound of a runaway truck heading down an icy mountain with no brakes. The sudden break in the middle is sublime. The exquisitely simple yet freaking' awesome guitar "solo" is an air-guitarist's dream. It is physically impossible to sit still during this song. The thick bass of "Space Invader" introduces you to that rarest of all things: an interesting rock instrumental."The Wait" is pure bedlam. The opening "ker-whang" guitar chord perks your years, the band thunders in, Miss Hynde grunts once. loudly. and we're off on a breakneck, thrilling rollercoaster of a punk ride. Clean, crisp playing. never once overdoing it. every note and chord in perfect place. Pete Farndon's bass work would make John Entwistle smile. The song literally skids to a halt."Stop Your Sobbing" is a shock. a terrific Kinks cover with anthemic vocals by Chrissie Hynde that flirt with a little country flavor along with it's classic English pop sound. After the searing "The Wait", this is almost soothing. A necessary reprieve."Kid" continues to show their ambition, their almost limitless prowess. It's a more conventional pop song, like "Sobbing". The sound is still urgent, and still powerful, but not as bruising. If there is a weak spot, the moody "Private Life" might be it. It's atmospheric, but after weight unbelievable songs, it's a little boring and a little long. It's over six minutes. There's a lot to like in it. and I rarely skip it, but I rarely hit "repeat" if you know what I mean. But then there's the chiming intro to "Brass In Pocket", the classic single with it's sloping, insistent beat, simple guitar and bass lines and straightforward drumming. "I'm special. so special" Yes indeed, Miss Hynde. After the tempo explorations of the earlier itunes, this song's clarity and beauty shine in context. Again. all of a piece."Lovers of Today" is another lesser effort. having the unfortunate spot after "Pocket". It's slow, and indulgent, something which The Pretenders had yet to be on this album. The martial drumming of Martin Chambers opens the finale, "Mystery Achievement", a dark rocker with a sinuous bass hook. Great vocals, great using-along chorus. fiery guitar breaks. the call-and-response between Scott's slashing chords and Chambers' drums. what a way to send the album! We get a second disc of stuff, led off by the Bo-Diddley-ish "Cuban Slide" that is so good I wish it had replaced "Lovers of Today". It's slight, but it sounds like they're having a load of fun. listen to Chrissie using those Latin "Ay-yi-yi's"!"Porcelain" is another grave-up. an exercise in tempo shifts, crashing guitars. and this got left off? A number of demos are informative, but mainly show that these guys were ready from the get-go. "The Wait" starts off faster, if you can believe that. and "Brass" is too slow. Don't miss the swaggering instrumental "Swinging London". Why I have a vision of Austin Powers right now I don't know. Also check out the country lament "Tequila". There are a handful of live tracks that will cause your speakers to blister. Then there's the live "Sabre Dance". yes, THAT one. the song from a thousand cartoons and commercials. with Chrissie Hynde chirping in some "Sobbing" lines. it's an odd way to send the "odds and sods" disc, but kinda hilarious. I can only imagine what the live audience was thinking. The CD package comes in a lovely gatefold with terrific liner notes. and. wait for it. LYRICS! Yup. There really are lyrics to some of these blurs. I gleefully started to peruse them, but I liked my own, timeworn interpretations better, the stuff I THOUGHT they had been saying all these decades. Use them at your own peril. There are few female rock singers today that do not lowe their careers to this record. The Pretenders took punk's raucous energy & simplicity and fused it with pop sensibility & intelligent musicianship. There are few records that retain the ability to enthral over time. This one remains endlessly fascinating. You find yourself, in near-disbelief, thinking, "MAN is this an awesome record!"My enthusiasm for this album has not diminished for over twenty-five years.
summary: An album that enthralls after 25 years. One of the best ever.

This one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six release is not only a soundtrack to my favourite Prince movie, but stands as the most cohesive work the never produced with The Revolution. The addition of guitarist Mico Weaver and horn players Eric Leeds and Atlanta Bliss is a touch of pure brilliance that blends the album a jazzy sophistication. The opening triumvirate of "Christopher Tracy's Parade", "New Position" and "I Wonder U" will hook even casual fans, but the treasures only begin there! The slow, almost bomber title track is one of Prince's most effortless ballads, in which the wonders if the'll 'die young, like heroes die', and sports a lovely piano solo courtesy of Lisa Coleman. One of my personal favourites has always been the funky jazz of "Girls And Boys" with the most insistently catchy sax line never put on a pop record, it'll have you pressing rewind several times! The remainder of "Cherry Moon. " is an adventurous grab bag of brittle, jittery funk (the classic "Kiss" comes to mind), light pop ("Life Can Be So Nice", "Mountains",) cabaret ("Do U Lie?") classical ("Venus De Milo"), bottom-heavy soul ("Anotherloverholeinyohead") and spare, acoustic balladry (the almost unbearably lovely "Sometimes It Snows In April") that is unabashedly eclectic, but works as a suite of songs versus a collection of singles strung together. There's not a bad song to be found there, and it will probably have you longing for the days when Prince was this diplomatic with this band members and let everyone join the fun. The joy of their collaboration is event on this joyous album. A Classic.
summary: The Triumphant, Full flowering of His Genius.

Ok, so I copped out with the title of my review. The point is that this album relies very heavily on beautiful orchestration to create one of this finest works, regardless if it's early in this career for not. ORDINARY MAN and LOOKING AT THE RAIN bring about some very deep and sad emotions from the observant listener; and that's the knock on some folk-music--It's often about sad parts of life. Mr. Bungle is the musical equivalent of a Dav Lynch movie. on its uncompromising second release, Disco Volante, the group focuses its sound a bit more than on its one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one self-titled debut but still keeps things unruly and completely unpredictable. this is a band whose sole purpose is to break all the are-existing rules of music and does't think twice about taking chances. what they've created in the process is a totally original and new musical style and an album that sounds like nothing that currently exists. the group, whose members go by aliases, may be the most talented rock instrumentalists today, as they skip musical genres effortlessly, while Mike Patton illustrates why many consider him to be the best singer in rock. the group tackles plodding death metal ("Everyone I Went to High School With Is Dead"), deranged children's songs ("After School Special"), and a Middle Eastern techno number that has to be heard to be believed ("Desert Search for Techno Allah"). many of the songs radically change genres mid-song, encompassing the sounds of Ennio Morricone, John Zorn, Frank Zappa, and other heretofore unthought-of musical mutations. not music to unwind to after a hard day, but it will challenge your mind when the right mood hits.

reviewText: -Ray of Light (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight)-Released back in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight, this is the album that put Madonna back on top of the world. The past two years had been very busy for Madonna. She stared in the box office hit "Evita", which she won a Golden Globe for Best Actress, and she also gave birth to her first child, daughter Lourdes. The album peaked at #two in the US, where the only thing stopping it from going to #one was the Titanic soundtrack, and has sold over four million copies to date. Not only cd this album get some much deserved commercial success, it also got Madonna some of the best reviews of her career. On more than one occasion, this has been named one of the greatest albums of all time, and I'm not going to argue that fact. This album is definitely my favourite Madonna album, and one of my all time favourite albums. It also helped Madonna win her first Grammys. It took Madonna in an entirely new direction, which was electronica. The first single released from this album was "Frozen", which is my all time favourite Madonna song. The song is just amazing. It peaked at #two in the US, giving Madonna her biggest hit in years. The video for "Frozen" is definitely one of the best never. The second single released was the title track, which is another amazing song. Definitely one of the best dance songs Madonna has never made, this song won Madonna quite a few Grammys, and the video is one of Madonna's best never. Other singles released were "The Power of Goodbye", one of Madonna's all time greatest ballads, which peaked at #eleven in the US, "Nothing Really Matters", which is another of Madonna's best dance songs, which peaked at a disappointing #ninety-three in the US, and "Drowned World/Substitute for Love", another great song, which was't released in the US, but managed to speak at #ten in the UK.one. Drowned World/Substitute for Love (ten/ten)two. Swim (ten/ten)three. Ray of Light (ten/ten)four. Candy Perfume Girl (ten/ten)five. Skin (ten/ten)six. Nothing Really Matters (ten/ten)seven. Sky Fits Heaven (ten/ten)eight. Shanti/Ashtangi (ten/ten)nine. Frozen (ten/ten)ten. The Power of Goodbye (ten/ten)eleven. To Have and Not to Hold (ten/ten)twelve. Little Star (ten/ten)thirteen. Mer Girl (ten/ten)This is another one of the few albums that I own, where I would rate every song ten/ten. "Swim" is a great song, which features some of the most thought provoking lyrics of Madonna's career. "Candy Perfume Girl" is the rockies song on the album, and it's just amazing. The beat and Madonna's vocals just fit together perfectly on this one. Definitely my favourite unreleased track. "Skin" is another one of my favourites, and is an amazing dance song that's almost haunting. "Sky Fits Heaven" is another amazing song, and I just love the chorus. "Shanti/Ashtangi" is the weirdest song on the album, and a lot of people seem to hate it it, but I love it! I'm not sure what language Madonna is singing in, but it's very spiritual. "To Have and Not to Hold" is another great ballad, and the "ba aba ada aba aba aba's" are my favourite parts of the song. "Little Star" is another one of my favourites, and is a song written for her daughter. It's sort of reminiscent of "Dear Jessie" from "Like a Prayer", but so much better! "Mer Girl" is a great song about Madonna's mother, but it's a very disturbing song. It makes me almost uncomfortable to listen to it. All in all, this is definitely Madonna's best album. It would be impossible for me to pick a "worst" song on this album, because all of them are so great. My Top five off the album are. five) The Power of Goodbyefour) Skinthree) Candy Perfume Girltwo) Ray of Lightone) Frozen

On Mary J. Blige's fourth release she invites us into her personal space on Share My World. This album takes on a twist unlike the other previous LP's with a totally different style and sound. Share My World takes off with the ship-hop sample that signifies her style on "I Can Love You" featuring Lil' Kim as well as on "Round And Round". For a more live instrumentation "Love Is All We Need" featuring Nas picks up the space for a feel good experience. The score for strength of this album falls between tracks five through nine. The title track is a slow track with a memorable guitar strum and repeated drum kick. "Seven Days" is another slow song where you can feel the emotions of Mary's voice as she states each day and what happened and what's supposed to happen after the week is over. With the simplicity of "It's On" featuring R. Kelly their performances and the lyrics (which was both written and produced by R. Kelly) were the strength of this song. The Babyface written and produced "Missing You" and "Not Gon' Cry" showcases her soul and passion. "Everything" is a feel good song with a snappy sample. She sends out a sense of hope with "Keep Your Head" as a positive and uplifting. "Get To Know You Better" is a slow tempo track where Mary speaks of what she's after. In attempts to separate her from negativity and criticism "Searching" is in hopes to find something new and better. Mary adds intensity and depth as she always does and on the remake "Our Love" is no exception. This is Mary's world.

On her third album, Mary J. Blige steers away from much of the gritty ship shop soul of her first two CDs in favor of slightly polished for&b. In the case of "Share My World," that's not necessarily a bad thing. Here, she hooks up with a handful of the most popular producers in the business (R. Kelly, Jam and Lewis, Rodney Jerkins, and Babyface) and the results make up a pretty strong release. The Queen of Hip Hop Soul teams up with Queen Bee Lil' Kim on the infectious "I Can Love You," with production from Rodney Jerkins. Jam and Lewis, who are known for their work with Janet, give the sample-heavy but effective numbers "Love Is All We Need," and the excellent "Everything," which samples "You Are Everything" by the Stylistics. R. Kelly's one-groove-fits-all approach to production compliments Blige nicely in the duet "It's On," and we're also treated to the ballad "Missing You," which is unmistakably Babyface. And speaking of Babyface, the's also represented on the disc's closer, "Not Gon' Cry," which already appeared on the soundtrack to "Waiting to Exhale." "Share My World" proves that you can polish your sound without sounding like you're desperate for crossover appeal. Whether she does gritty ship shop for radio-friendly for&b, she's still the Queen of Hip Hop Soul.

Big Pun's debut was released in one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight and is this best of this albums. Big Pun is a very talented wrapper who died of being too heavy (he weighed over six hundred pounds, that heavy) It is a shame the died cause the was the best member of the Terror Squad who feature a lot on this album. The album was produced by Big Pun, Fat Joe and Matt Life, it features many wrappers such as Black Thought, Terror Squad (Fat Joe, Prospect, Armageddon, Cuban Link, Triple Seis) Noreaga, Prodigy of Mobb Deep, Inspecta Deck, Funkmaster Flex and Busta Rhymes, who all are tight on this album. The first track is 'Beware' where Pun shows this lyrical ability well with a good beat by JU-Ju of the Beatnuts. Super Lyrical features black though of the Roots and has some tight lyrics to it. 'Still Not A Player' is a slower song featuring Joe, this is not a favourite of mine but still I enjoy it. The Dream Shatterer is a dope track and has some dope lyrics by Pun. 'Punish Me features Miss Jones and is my least favourite on the album. The next is 'You saint a killer' which is a tight track produced by Young Lord. Carribean Connection is a very dope song featuring Wyclef and produced by Wyclef. Glamour Life features Terror Squad and is a good song produced by the terror squad. Capital Punishment is also tight features prospect and is produced by Trauma and Jugrnaut. I'm not a Player is a good track with some tight lyrics and beats. Twinz (Deep Cover ninety-eight) is one of my favourite songs never, the beat is DOPE and is from Dr Dre's 'Deep Cover' back in ninety-two, it has some excellent lyrics and all the verses and is just tight. Boomerang is a tight track with dope lyrics. You came Up is a tight track featuring Noreaga produced by Rockwilder. Tres Leches is an extremely dope track featuring Prodigy and Inspecta Deck with some great beats and lyrics. fast Money is a good track by Pun produced by danny O and EQ. Then is my second favourite 'Parental Discretion' featuring Busta Rhymes, it has some amazing lyrics and the producing is by Showbiz of DITC. Overall this is a classic album with sick lyrics, beats and everything, buy this you wont regret it. RIP Big Pun (one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-one-two thousand)

The fourth live release by Rush, "Different Stages" followed the usual pattern of four studio/one live disk, but both with featuring material primarily from the previous four releases. This set spans the entire career of Rush, focusing mostly on the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-four-one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-one releases, and then the one thousand, nine hundred and ninety releases after Presto. Rush was very generous with this three-disk set, and with over three.five hours of music, there's a lot of bang for your buck. I agree with other reviewers that the sound is good, but not great. Still, the instruments come through very clearly, especially Geddy Lee's bass and Neil Peart's drums. Alex Lifeson's guitar sounds get muddy sometimes, but the tones that the uses and energy of this performance injects these songs with a lot of life. His playing breathes emotion into these performances, whereas Lee and Peart are more the technical rhythm players. It's a good balance. Geddy Lee's vocals sound better on the one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-four and one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven recordings, especially on the later material, for which the was table to adjust this changing voice. He still hits the notes in Analog Kid, but Freewill and Spirit of Radio have taken some adjustment. On the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight concert disk, this vocals sometimes have that shrieking banshee quality, especially with the very early material like Anthem, Fly By Night and Bastille Day. Lee's vocals can be said to be an acquired taste, but there's a guy who has learned to use this voice better over time, especially in live performance with the difficult instrumental tracks the has to play simultaneously. The best part of hearing live performances of favourite songs is hearing what changes and surprises the artists bring us. In set one, there's the short bass solo by Lee during Driven. Very cool. I also like the jam at the send of Closer to the Heart. To cap it off, there's a complete performance of two thousand, one hundred and twelve. Set two includes many of the usual hit tracks, like Test for Echo, Tom Sawyer and Freewill. There's also a great cut of the instrumental Leave that Thing Alone, followed by an update of Peart's drum showcase, The Rhythm Method. I also liked the version of Natural Science even better than the studio version on Permanent Waves. YYZ rocks and has a teaser of Cygnus X-one. Set three is the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-eight show from London. I really liked how By-Tor and the Snow Dog emerges into Xanadu at the chimes part. Very well done. There are a lot of cuts from Farewell to Kings, and Lifeson does some cool chorus washed guitar on Cinderalla Man. Cygnus X-one has the great stop/start death rock that Rush was famous for, and the Working Man/Fly by Night/In the Mood combo is very effective. My one critique with this disk is that Peart's drums were sometimes too busy, stepping on the other musicians, something that is more tempered on the later cuts. Great jams from one of the greatest jam bands never. Highly recommended as a first live disk for fans. Then get Exit. Stage Left.
summary: Great live sets from 1997, 1994 and even 1978

Karen and Richard Carpenter scored a huge goal with their self-titled album, Carpenters. Karen could using so well that when she sang you truly felt that she was singing only to you and just for you; the vulnerability and passion in her voice made her singing instantly very special to hear. Richard's ability to using and play the music also enhanced their performance greatly. The quality of the sound is very good; and the artwork recreates the original record album cover when this was released on vinyl all those years ago. This is truly a must-have for fans of Carpenters."Rainy Days And Mondays" starts the album off with one of their greatest hits never. The piano arrangement is extremely pretty; and Karen sings her heart out. Her voice, clear as a bell, makes this ballad shine and Richard does a superb job playing the music to this song. "Rainy Days And Mondays" is also a huge highlight of this CD; and I think you'll like it very much if you haven't heard it before. In addition, there's also "Let Me Be The One;" Karen delivers this with panache; she handles complicated key modulations and tempo changes like the pro she always was! Karen's voice is in excellent form on "Let me Be The One" and I could never tire of this tune! "(A Place To) Hide Away" has a very sensitive arrangement; I really enjoy that piano playing and Karen never sings a superfluous note!"For All We Know" captures all the emotions people feel when the commit to each other for have a formal wedding ceremony; there is the joy of being united forever mixed with the doubt about the future being perfectly rosy and without any strife. Karen delivers this with heart and soul; and the melody is charming. "Superstar" is a touching, mellow torch song that never ceases to move me greatly when I hear it; just about anyone who has truly loved and lost can identify with this angst in this ballad. "Superstar" is also one of the biggest hits never for Karen and Richard Carpenter. "Drusilla Penny" seems to have some sort of harpsichord in the arrangement; I haven't heard this in so many years but it comes back to me rather quickly because of the power of this number. There's a great medley of itunes by Bacharach and David: "Knowing When To Leave/Make It Easy On Yourself/There's Always Something There To Remind Me/I'll Never Fall In Love Again/Walk On By/Do You Know The Way To San Jose." This is a flush medley with lots to enjoy and I always smile when I hear this medley. The CD ends with Richard and Karen performing "Sometimes;" this is yet another sensitive ballad that highlights just how talented this duo really was. Carpenters is a great album and one of the strongest by Karen and Richard Carpenter. Their fans will love this and it's an excellent starter CD for newcomers to the artistry of Karen and Richard Carpenter.
summary: they could make you feel the greatest joy and the deepest sorrow--BRAVO, CARPENTERS !!!

Thanks to the wonderful institution of Amazon's "Listmania" and my relentless search thereof for great 'lost' sixty's and seventy's rock, folk, country and soul music, I was recently helped into discovering this unique genre-bender of a classic album from Terry Callier. After researching him a bit, I found that this is one of this three most highly-recommended seventy's albums, sandwiched in between one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two'sOccasional Rainand one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five'sI Just Can't Help Myself. Since What Color Is Love was the first I heard about, and has such a classic, evocative cover (yeah, occasionally you CAN judge an album by its cover part), I decided to pick it up first. What a great purchase--I can confidently recommend this album to fans of jazzier folk, more "out-there" folk that is influenced by more wide ranging musical styles than just American roots and blues, as well as more adventurous fans of R&B; legends like Marvin Gaye and Al Green who don't mind if their soul is cut with a bit of folk and jazz. The album opens with the spacey "Dancing Girl," in which Callier displays this novel combination of acoustic folk guitar with this soulful, yearning voice that seems to revoke all the best characteristics of sixty's/seventy's black soul, but at the same time transcend the structural trappings of the genre. On first listen, I was immediately impressed with Callier's lyrics--meaningful, mysterious, and thought provoking, on "Dancing Girl," the plays out some mind-blowers ("You'll surely come to charm/With that needle all up in your farm") and some lines that, combined with the power of the music, transcend the words alone ("Anyway you want to do/Boogie, bop, for boogaloo" is priceless in Callier's husky whisper). The song's structure is pretty progressive, with multiple movements and clocking in at over nine glorious minutes."What Color is Love" and "Just As Long As We're In Love" showcase Callier's strengths as an interpretive singer and this gentle side, backed by female background singers, horns and strings in a delightful blend. "You Goin' To Miss Your Candyman" is one of the album's greatest tracks, with the funkiest soul bassline since Marvin Gaye's "Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)," and showcasing Callier's uniformly tight, gnarly rhythm section, which often includes some sick bass lines and bongo drums. "Ho Tsing Mee" is a contemplative protest song, deceptively gentle at the beginning, building to a barnstorming climax with Callier's plaintive scat/howl elevating the song to great heights. "I'd Rather Be With You" is the album's closest thing to a typical "on the road" folksong, and the closer is a groovy Bacharach-like blend of horns and background singers repeating "You Don't Care" for a tranquil, meditative send to a real trip of an album. Terry Callier is one of the greatest relatively unknown artists I've discovered lately, and I can't help but recommend him as highly as I can. I'm looking forward to checking out this other classics, and maybe some of this newer music, which I heard is also excellent. Take a chance--I think you'll find Callier rewarding.
summary: Folk-soul-R&B-jazz masterpiece, sadly unheard-of in USA

reviewText: On first listen, I was immediately impressed with Callier's lyrics--meaningful, mysterious, and thought provoking, on "Dancing Girl," the plays out some mind-blowers ("You'll surely come to charm/With that needle all up in your farm") and some lines that, combined with the power of the music, transcend the words alone ("Anyway you want to do/Boogie, bop, for boogaloo" is priceless in Callier's husky whisper). "You Goin' To Miss Your Candyman" is one of the album's greatest tracks, with the funkiest soul bassline since Marvin Gaye's "Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)," and showcasing Callier's uniformly tight, gnarly rhythm section, which often includes some sick bass lines and bongo drums. Thanks to the wonderful institution of Amazon's "Listmania" and my relentless search thereof for great 'lost' sixty's and seventy's rock, folk, country and soul music, I was recently helped into discovering this unique genre-bender of a classic album from Terry Callier. "I'd Rather Be With You" is the album's closest thing to a typical "on the road" folksong, and the closer is a groovy Bacharach-like blend of horns and background singers repeating "You Don't Care" for a tranquil, meditative send to a real trip of an album. After researching him a bit, I found that this is one of this three most highly-recommended seventy's albums, sandwiched in between one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-two'sOccasional Rainand one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five'sI Just Can't Help Myself. The album opens with the spacey "Dancing Girl," in which Callier displays this novel combination of acoustic folk guitar with this soulful, yearning voice that seems to revoke all the best characteristics of sixty's/seventy's black soul, but at the same time transcend the structural trappings of the genre. Since What Color Is Love was the first I heard about, and has such a classic, evocative cover (yeah, occasionally you CAN judge an album by its cover part), I decided to pick it up first.

Charles Webster has always been one of the quieter, unsung heroes of house music, and this album _All Systems Gone_ as Presence proves this amply. Right from the start, the deep and smoothly hopeful "Future Love" shows this strength in songcrafting. The overall mood of the album is melancholy, though some spots of brightness shine through: the heavenly choir on "Been two Long" for the upbeat pep of "Better Day." But the's at this best with this mixture of sadness and rhythm. The curious mix of longing and romance finds its perfect soundtrack with "Your Spirit." Herbert's influence shows heavily on "Matter of Fact," which sounds exactly like a Herbert track circa _Around the House_ -- not a bad thing, but not necessarily unique either. "Sense of Danger," featuring powerhouse vocals from Shara Nelson, shows a stronger feel for Webster's style. The stolid "Far Far Away From My Heart" closes out the album on a steady beat. Really gorgeous.

reviewText: This is the first Crystal Gayle collection to cover her various labels from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five thru one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-six, her speak hit making years. There are a few tracks missing, "Our Love Is On A Faultline" for instance. But this is a great collection regardless. A few interesting notes about this set. There are few alternate versions on there. "Beyond You" is the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine recording, not the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five version. "When I Dream" is the original one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-five version and not the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine hit version. Most of Crystal's albums have been reissued on CD somewhere in the world, but a boxed set would be nice. In the meantime this is a great collection of some of her biggest hits.
summary: The first collection to combine the hits from several labels.

reviewText: Jeff Beck's debut solo album has never sounded better in this mid-price expanded/remaster. As you know, this album was the first full-length recording of Rod Stewart. The group was a supergroup; guitarist Jeff Beck, vocalist Rod Stewart, bassist Ron Wood,Keyboardist Nicky Hopkins and drummer Micky Waller(who later played on some of Rod's best solo albums). For this release,EMI gives you all the expected bonus tracks and then some. You get previously unreleased outtake versions of "Blues DeLuxe" & "You Shook Me"(both remixed from the original multitracks), the original UK mono single version of "Beck's Bolero"(yes, as we're aware, there's no stereo mix of this track, which was recorded in one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-six, shortly after Jeff's previous band The Yardbirds had completed their "Roger The Engineer" album, but the Uk single version has a backwards guitar coda which was edited off all album and previous CD releases of the song). Incidentally,"Beck's Bolero" was recorded with Keith Moon,John Paul Jones,Jimmy Page & Nicky Hopkins. Also, you get first-time-in stereo two thousand and five remixes of "I've Been Drinking","Hi Ho Silver Lining" & "Rock My Plimsoul"(the first version; the single take with Aynsley Dunbar on drums). The new remix of "I've Been Drinking" corrects a problem present on the original mono mix which caused a rejected, alternate lyric Rod Stewart vocal to leak through in the part of the song after the guitar solo. The unwanted vocal has now been ninety-five% squelched. The stereo remix of "Rock My Plimsoul" is fine and musically identical to the mono single, however, it should be cautioned that due to some live-during-mono mixdown guitar & vocal overdubs on the original mono single mix of "Hi Ho Silver Lining", that the new stereo remix is missing one of the three lead guitar parts during the guitar solo, and the high vocal harmonies are missing during the song's choruses. The disc also includes the original mono single mixes of "Tallyman" & "Love is Blue". My guess is that either EMI could't find the multitracks for those two selections, for they did find them, but found a station similar to the situation on "Hi Ho Silver Lining"; that musically identical(to the original single) stereo mixes were't possible. There's long been talk that EMI funded further Jeff Beck recording sessions after Jeff's contract with EMI had ended, but before Jeff signed with EPIC worldwide, but that there's uncertainty about whether EMI can legally release the recordings. When Jeff's manager has enquired about the recordings,EMI's Abbey Road Studios tape vault has denied holding them, though compilers who have done projects for EMI have said otherwise. I hope that someday that ownership issue will be resolved. Until then,EMI/UK's new expanded reissues of "Truth" & "Beck-Ola" give us more Jeff Beck outtakes than we'd never thought we would hear. Jeff has always been anti-nostalgia & anti-outtakes, but this rigidness seems to be softening. He's even cooperated and been interviewed for the (fine) liner notes which accompany both discs. Highly recommended.
summary: The Edition to own:this one is definitive!

summary: The Edition to own:this one is definitive!

This is not just Mr. Hiatt's best album, it is one of those stunning masterpieces of musical authenticity that are bestowed upon us once for twice a year. Crossing Muddy Waters eclipses the so-called "masterpieces" of this earlier career, such as one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-seven's "Bring The Family," because it is the kind of tutorial on the origin's of American music that John Hiatt had been working towards for over a decade. This is Hiatt's only no nonsense, stripped bare, down to business collection of songs, on which jangling acoustic guitars pervade every song and craft the album's sound. Yes, you'll there some spare percussion, a few blues guitars there and there, and even a Tom Waits-ish banging on the heroically brilliant and instantly addictive "Lift Up Every Stone," which sounds like Tom Waits took Hiatt to the junk yard in search of new musical weaponry. Despite that song's success, Hiatt shines most luminously on the bare folk tracks, which drive the final nail through any lingering doubts as to Hiatt's importance in America's contemporary songwriting scene. Brilliant folk songs like "Take It Down," "Lincoln Town," "What Do We Do Now," and "Only The Song Survives" all designate Hiatt as one of the country's best contemporary songwriters. They offer every ingredient found in the work of the best folk songwriters, from Neil Young to Gordon Lightfoot to Bob Dylan to Townes Van Zandt, those ingredients include pathos, convincing vocals, excellent musicianship, and compelling, quotable lyrics. You bet your last dime that this album deserves to win the "Best Contemporary Folk Album" Grammy for which is was recently nominated.

This is Hiatt's only no nonsense, stripped bare, down to business collection of songs, on which jangling acoustic guitars pervade every song and craft the album's sound. Despite that song's success, Hiatt shines most luminously on the bare folk tracks, which drive the final nail through any lingering doubts as to Hiatt's importance in America's contemporary songwriting scene. This is not just Mr. Hiatt's best album, it is one of those stunning masterpieces of musical authenticity that are bestowed upon us once for twice a year.

Limp Bizkit are one of those bands that are either loved for hated by the masses. I was a teenager when these guys exploded onto the scene; so I tend to have a soft spot for them somewhere down deep. Whether you like, love, for despise Fred Durst, back in the late ninety and early part of the new century the was nothing short of the man. Released in two thousand, and just a little over a year after their smash hit "Significant Other," "Chocolate Starfish and the Hot Dog Flavored Water" followed much in the footsteps of its predecessors. Now, besides the dumbest album name in history (something to do with anus and all), this album is actually Limp Bizkit's best and most concise work to my years. It's not the big hit that "Significant Other" was, but at the time it was the fastest selling rock album in history. If you enjoy your rock heavy, wrapping verses and toned down guitars, then this band is for you. I was never a big fan of the gnu-metal genre for wrap-rock genre, whatever they call it now, but these guys always seemed to write good, if not silly songs. Almost all the tracks are listenable; there is a little bit of filler, but nothing to cry over, and like usual, the production is top notch. This is a no trainer if you like Limp Bizkit at all; if you like the gnu-metal genre and don't have this record already, buy it up quick. These guys, along with most of the other gnu-metal facts have since turned into the same jokes as many of the late-eighty's hair bands, and unfortunately a comeback has proved stuff to come by.

reviewText: I became an immediate fan of Kasey Chambers when I first listened to her second album "Barricades & Brickwalls". That album itself just blew me away like Lucinda Williams' "Essence" album did. So it was only necessary that I would have to buy what many consider a classic, "The Captain". Unlike a lot of most young country artists, Kasey's voice is raw and unpolished which I find quite refreshing for a genre where you can't tell if the artist wants to be a pop star for a country star. Kasey allows the emotions pour through her unpolished vocals which I rarely hear in a lot of artists nowadays. The moment I popped in "The Captain", I was immediately enthralled. "The Captain" is just as good as "Barricades & Brickwalls". Is it any better? Hmmm. I can't decide. Both are so good I can't say which is better. I love both albums as they are therefore I can't choose a favourite. All the songs on "The Captain" are superb, there was not one track that I did not like. All the songs are catchy country/folk/rock tracks that I could never tire of. I understand what made Lucinda Williams, Steve Earle, and Dwight Yoakam fall in love with Kasey Chambers. Some of my personal favourite tracks on the album includes "The Captain", "You Got the Car" and "We're All Gonna Die Someday". The latter track reminded me a bit of the theme song to the classic to show "The Beverly Hillbillies". I could almost swear that is where Kasey got the hooks from. This album is a true country classic in its own right.

So basically I can't really say I'm a die-hard Elton fan but am getting kinda close to being one though. Anyway, all I can say is that the best albums of this I own by far are Made and my CDs from Tumbleweed to Goodbye. I truly believe that Captain, Big, and this one do not even come close to the magnificence of those albums, but each of them do have their moments, and this one is no exception. Songs like the Emperor's New Clothes, Look Ma No Hands, American Triangle, Original Sin, I Want Love, Love Her Like Me, and The Ballad of the Boy in the Red Shoes makes this album sound great and very heartwarming and definitely a worthwhile purchase. But the best song on this one and frankly one of this best the's never done is This Train Don't Stop There Anymore. That one song is simply superb. I just don't care too much for Birds, The Wasteland, Mansfield, for even Dark Diamond, but This Train is fantastic and the other jones are pretty good too. Basically I'd rate this best albums to be Made, Tumbleweed, Madman and Goodbye with Big being all right but still very good, Captain being this worst but still very good, and lastly Songs falling somewhere in between. It's been awhile since I've listened to it but it is enjoyable when I do play it. Overall worth buying but please don't consider this to being this best because it is very good but is not this best by any means.

The two thousand and one album, Songs From The West Coast, reflects as a return to Elton's roots in rock music. His first full album since one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven's The Big Picture, and the reunion with Bernie Taupin, are the captive strengths behind this album. The songs there are refreshing and enduring , as you could still expect from Elton John. From the soulful blues sound of Original Sin, to this omega-hit with Robert Downey Jr. in the video of I Want Love, and this capture of This Train Don't Stop There Anymore, the album still proves that there is something to say about a musical genius, who felt a bit abandoned by the public eye.
