reviewText: One time Styx keyboard player/singer/songwriter Dennis DeYoung released this first solo album Desert Moon in September of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four. The album came to be after Dennis' Styx bandmate guitarist/singer/songwriter Tommy Shaw walked from the band during the mixing sessions of the band's Caught in the Act double live album. After Tommy resigned, guitarist James "JY" Young and The Panozzo brothers (John on drums and Chuck on bass guitar) wanted to push Styx forward but Dennis said no. Until Tommy was ready to come back, Dennis went in the studio in the spring of one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four to record this first solo album producing, playing keyboards, singing and writing all of the tracks (except as noted). Helping Dennis was guitarist Tom Dziallo (who is still Dennis' guitarist in this solo band), drummer Tom Radtke and sax-man Steve Eisen (who appeared on the final three Styx albums of the classic lineup). I was first exposed to the album thanks to (partially being a Styx fan by this point at page weight) and also the title cut's exposure on MTV and I got the forty-five with Desert Moon and Gravity. A week later, I got the album on cassette tape in December, one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-four and managed to wear this album out. For years tried to replace but only could get cassettes and then A&M; Records are-released the album with remastered sound in two thousand and one on CD and what an album. We open with the rocker "Don't Wait For Heroes" which is inspirational and fun and the second single from the album. The video for this said what the lyrics stated the real winners "are losers who get up and give it one more try" and a message that rings true to those who had to overcome being told no. Next is another up-tempo rocker in "Please" which features Rosemary Butler (famed for her duet vocal on Jackson Browne's "Stay" on this Running on Empty album in one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-seven and her work with Linda Ronstadt) duetting with Dennis and the song rocks. Next is the heights New Wave rock style meets fifty style singing Broadway number "Boys Will Be Boys" which is a fun and uplifting number and a guilty pleasure of mine. The first side ends with "Fire" which is a bluesy remake of the one thousand, nine hundred and sixty-seven Jimi Hendrix original (and yes, it does indeed hold its own) and Tommy Dziallo did the bluesy arrangement of this track. The second side starts with Desert Moon's title track which reached #ten on the Billboard singles chart which speaks of the things one lost from childhood and gained from adulthood though memories from the past don't leave. Next is "Suspicious" which is a nice mid-tempo number and features great guitar work from Dziallo and a superb synthesizer solo at the send from DeYoung. Next is "Gravity" which is another great rocker and an awesome song. We close the album with the ballad "Dear Darling (I'll Be There)". Desert Moon was Dennis' first, and to date only, successful project outside of Styx. The album hit #twenty-nine on the Billboard album charts and sold over five hundred, zero copies going Gold in the process. For those who want Dennis DeYoung solo works outside of Styx go with this album and the upcoming One Hundred Years From Now (which is this best solo work since this album). Highly recommended!
summary: One time Styx mastermind's solo debut is still a masterpiece 25 years later

Okay, first of all, I have to admit that on first listen, I wish the song had a few more "grinding" songs, a la OTHERSIDE for SUCK MY KISS for GIVE IT AWAY. I mean, those are some of the great RHCP songs!!! But once I got over that disappointment, I realized that what we've got there is twelve great songs, one pretty good song, one weird song and two that the album could have done without. I WOULD DIE FOR YOU and MIDNIGHT are the two I always skip. Just a bit unimaginative a monotonous. The weird one is WARM TAPE. Sometimes I hear it and it sounds cheesy, and other times it's almost sexy. Certainly the lyric "Shiver for me girl" is a good one! I can't describe the song though. You've got to hear it for yourself. The pretty good song is THE ZEPHYR SONG, which is getting a lot of airplay. It's okay, kinda breezy, but just does't revoke any strong feelings. The rest of the album is absolutely top notch. These guys can really write the itunes now. CALIFORNICATION (which is brilliant too) served as a kind of bridge from their rougher, earlier stuff to these textured, complex melodies. The hit single BY THE WAY, which kicks off the album is INSTANTLY, INSTANTLY, INSTANTLY catchy. I was ready to using along halfway through the song on the first listen. Other standouts include the driving CAN'T STOP, the delightful UNIVERSALLY SPEAKING and the latin-flavored CABRON. Lyrically, the songs are often difficult to grasp. Don't look for linear meaning. They revoke moods, feelings and random images. But Anthony Kiedis sings with real feeling, and the musicianship is first rate all the way through. They all do their best work as musicians and songwriters, never. Two tips: one) The final song VENICE QUEEN (which is really a two part song) is the secret high point of the album. It builds with a gorgeous, quiet riff and grows in power. It could almost have been on Californication, with its West-Coast centric imagery, but I find it a bracing conclusion to this album. two) Listen to the album with headphones. there is SO much subtlety that you easily miss otherwise, especially some of the grace notes and such that guitarist John Frusciante throws in. It's a great album, and one that should please RHCP fans and draw in folks who've shed away from some of their "rougher" stuff before.

I love, love, love this CD!! I purchased it when it initially came out and liked it a lot, but it's one of those CD's that gets better with each listen so I wanted to let those people who love pop in it's purest form to give this a try. Daniel Bedingfield has put together a great collection of songs (a little of everything) and it all works so well that the singles keep coming at the listener and they could all be potential singles. The problem with Daniel is that the is difficult to market as this songs are pure pop music that will please both the TRL crowd and older listeners who tend to have a bias against what they may incorrectly perceive a kiddie-pop. But no review of this release can be comprehensive if it does not address the warmth of Bedingfield's voice. Without the histrionics of some of this counterparts, the does manage to leave a strong impression by feeling, not just hitting (or doing vocal gymnastics) the highs and flows. I particularly like the flow of the release and was surprised that it was self-produced. What I find astonishing is that one can clearly see the influence of US pop and R&B; music on this release, but instead of being a knock-off, Bedingfield seems to surpass all this influences. Among my favourites:Gotta Get Thru ThisIf You're Not the OneI Can't Read YouFridayJames Dean (I Wanna Know)GirlfriendHonest QuestionI think that you get the point. I love all (expect selection five) songs and one less than stellar song stills merits a five. Unless it was a fluke, which I highly doubt, this UK import will eventually rule the US airwaves as the has in this native England.

The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash was on the radio in the mid one thousand, nine hundred and sixty's singing the funny yet catching country song "A Man Named Sue" which everyone sang along. The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash sang a movie track, I was shocked by the non-metered poetry. My father said "Johnny Cash is known to tell a story rather than using in rhyme." Years later through Classical music I learned that one was allowed to do such a thing. The "First Time Ever I" never bought a Johnny Cash CD was "Johnny Cash's Greatest Hits Volume I" because I collect music to match with my slide shows & don't play this type of CDs for normal listening pleasure. The "First Time Ever I" heard Johnny Cash sang "Hurt" was at work a few years ago. All day long my business environment is a battle ground between Rap & Mex-Tex. All of a sudden a deep worn out voice sang about spiritual depravity & hope that I was blown away. "Who is singing?" I asked a fellow worker who also does't listen to Rap for Mex-Tex. Some of my favourites include: Nobody's Listening, Faint, Numb, Hit the Floor, and Somewhere I Belong. It's kinda cool that this hard-rocking band don't serve out songs with cussing for obscene overtones. Linkin Park is a classy and respected band. Highly recommend this great and satisfying disc. Linkin Park rules!

Mariah Carey is known to be one of the greatest Divas of all time. In two thousand and three, Mariah Carey had released her thirteenth album entitled, "The Remixes", a double-disc album that features many of Mariah Carey's greatest songs, all remixed. Some of the songs were remixed by studio equipment. Others were remixed by Mariah are-recording the songs with different music and lyrics. This remix album is absolutely amazing in every way. Disc One: Studio Produced Dance Club RemixesMY ALL (Morales "My" Club Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). The original version of "My All", which can be found on Mariah Carey's "Butterfly" album, is a beautiful ballad, that is composed with a beautiful Spanish sound. Who knew that a beautiful ballad that requires slow-dancing, can be remixed into a version where you can get your groove on?(Medley) HEARTBREAKER/IF YOU SHOULD EVER BE LONELY (Junior's "Heartbreaker" Club Mix)Original version of "Heartbreaker" from the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). New song. Mariah had remixed the music of Heartbreaker and remixed her vocals, all by studio equipment. But also extended the song, in order for her to record, "If You Should Ever Be Lonely (Deep In The Night)", making this remix of "Heartbreaker" a medley, instead of only being a remix. So, it is a remix medley. This is an incredible remix medley. FLY AWAY (BUTTERFLY REPRISE) (Fly Away Club Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Incredible dance remix. ANYTIME YOU NEED A FRIEND (C&C; Club Version)Original version from the album Music Box (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three). Although, this remix is great to dance to, I prefer the ballad version. FANTASY (Def Club Mix)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). Not bad. HONEY (Classic Mix)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Not bad. DREAMLOVER (Def Club Mix)Original version from the album Music Box (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-three). I prefer this dance remix over the original version. EMOTIONS (twelve" Club Mix)Original version from the album Emotions (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-one). This is much better than the original version. THROUGH THE RAIN (HQtwo Radio Edit)Original version from the album Charmbracelet (two thousand and two). Both the original version, which was recorded as a ballad, and this incredible dance version are unbelievable. Disc Two: Re-Recorded RemixesFANTASY (Remix) (featuring O. D. B.)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). Remix from the album #one's (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight). The music to the song was remixed a bit, Mariah's vocals are untouched, except for the choruses. The original choruses are taken out and are replaced by the bridge of the song. Ol' Dirty Bastard hit the studio to provide this dieting vocals to the song. An incredible remix. ALWAYS BE MY BABY (Mr. Dupri Mix) (featuring Da Brat & Xscape)Original version from the album Daydream (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five). The music was completely remixed and Mariah's vocals are untouched. Da Brat & Xscape had hit the studio to provide their dieting craps to the song. Great remix.(Medley) MY ALL/STAY AWHILE (So So Def Remix) (featuring Lord Tariq & Peter Gunz)Original version of "My All" from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). This medley was treated the same way as "(Medley) Heartbreaker/If You Should Ever Be Lonely", only Mariah brought in Lord Tariq & Peter Gunz to provide craps for the song. Hate it. THANK GOD I FOUND YOU (Make It Last Remix) (featuring Joe & Naz)Original version from the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). The original version of "Thank God I Found You" was composed as a ballad, where Mariah Carey had ninety-eight Degrees & Joe on that version. That version is the one I prefer. The music to the song was remixed, where Mariah Carey are-recorded the verses with Joe, and Nas. Hate it. BREAKDOWN (featuring Krazyzie Bone & Wishbone of Bone Thugs 'N Harmony)From the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). I don't why she included this song because it is not a remix. I hate this song. HONEY (So So Def Mix) (featuring Da Brat & JD)Original version from the album Butterfly (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-seven). Not a bad remix. LOVERBOY (Remix) (featuring Ludacris, Shawnna, Da Brat, & Twenty II)From the album Glitter (two thousand and one). Both the album version & this remix are featured on Mariah's album, "Glittler". The album version is a duet with Cameo. This remix is no different from the original version. The music is untouched, Mariah's vocals are untouched. The song is just extended in order for Ludacris, Shawnna, Da Brat, & Twenty II to provide their craps. Cameo's verse has been taken out. Great remix. HEARTBREAKER (Remix) (featuring Da Brat & Missy Elliott)From the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). Both the original version & this remix are featured on Mariah's album entitled, "Rainbow". The original version is a duet with Jay-Z. This remix is very different from the original version. The music to the original took up a Pop/Rap sound. The music to this remix is strictly a Rap sound. Mariah Carey did are-record the first two verses. She kept the original lyrics to the first verse and sang them in the same key as the original, but she sang it a little more sexier. But the second verse was changed, with different lyrics, where Mariah sang it in a different key. The choruses are kept the same. Da Brat & Missy Elliott provide their own craps. Great remix. SWEETHEART (featuring JD)From the album #one's (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-eight). Don't believe what you read. The album version is the version you see there: a duet with JD. There is no remix, as far as I'm concerned. Not bad. CRYBABY (featuring Snoop Dogg)From the album Rainbow (one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-nine). Don't believe what you read. The album version is the version you see there: a duet with Snoop Dogg. There is no remix, as far as I'm concerned. Hate it. MISS YOU (featuring Jadakiss)Previously unreleased. This song is not a remix. This song was included on the UK release of Mariah's album, "Charmbracelet". Most fans liked the song, but could not get it on the U. S. release of "Charmbracelet", for any of Mariah's single releases. So, she included it there. THE ONE (So So Def Mix) (featuring Bonecrusher)Previously unreleased. Hate it. I KNOW WHAT YOU WANT (featuring Busta Rhymes & The Flipmode Squad)From Busta Rhymes' album It Ain't Safe No More (two thousand and two). Most fans really enjoyed this song because Busta actually sings on it, instead of wrapping. I don't care for this song. This is an album, in which Mariah's fans had been waiting for. Not all the songs on this album are worth the time, in my opinion, but most of the album is definitely worth the money. Anyway, take out your wallets and buy the remixes you've been wanting to own since Mariah's debut.

Instead of the forced whimsy of White Pepper we find The Brothers Ween going off in the direction of the earlier album's mixture of effacement and ambition. Personally, I am greatful. Whereas many bands when creating whimsy revoke Syd Barrett and Robyn Hitchcock, Ween scares up Residents flashbacks (ie "Neighborhood")amidst subtle spokes at the Prog Rock camp. reviewText: Ever since I heard the honest single "Player's Ball", from their debut CD "Southernplayalisticadillacmuzik", I have been a fan of Outkast. This CD opened doors for lot of groups from the South that are around now. I could give you a page long list of my favourite songs from Outkast. They always give you an innovative sound each time around. They also are not afraid to try new things. "ATliens", "Aquemini", and "Stankonia" are classic albums just as much as their debut CD was. Sometimes, it this hard to follow a blueprint when your fans expect you to create the hits like "Elevators", "Rosa Parks", "B. O. B", "Ms. Jackson" and "So Fresh And So Clean". With "Speakerboxxx/The Love Below", Outkast has brought you one solo CD from Big Boi and one solo CD from Andre three thousand. Although they are packaged together, you will clearly see that both of these CDs are entirely different from one another. Big Boi does't stray too far away from the Outkast sound. The Andre three thousand produced "Ghettomusick" is a fast paced roller coaster ride that only slows down long enough for a Patti Labelle sample. Big Boi drops a memorable sixteen bars and Outkast fans will not be disappointed at all. "Unhappy" has Big Boi talking about someone who might as well try to have a little fun before there misfortunes send up catching with them. "Bowtie" falls right in line with the honest single from "Speakerboxxx", "The Way You Move". Sleepy Brown is featured on both songs and they are both "feel good" type of songs. He definitely made the right choice for the first single with "The Way You Move" as Big Boi's fast paced craps are slowed down with Sleepy Brown's voice and an orchestra full of horns. This is definitely one of Speakerboxxx's better tracks. "The Rooster" has a "Ms. Jackson" feel to it, but it won't make you miss "Ms. Jackson" at all. You'll probably laugh at what the is saying if anything. "Church" is another one of those "feel good" songs from Big Boi. If you karen't careful, you might even wake up in a pew. "War" is a song that you will actually try to listen to what the is saying eventhough the song has two different beats to it. "Tomb Of The Boom" is a lyrical free for all between Big Boi, Ludacris, Big Gipp from Gooide Mob and Konkrete. This is another one of my favourite songs from "Speakerboxxx" so far and Big Boi definitely dropped a nice beat for the song. "Flip Flop Rock" has Big Boi, Jay Z and Killer Mike wrapping over a fast paced beat and the collaboration works once again as the three MCs were already featured with Twista on Jay Z's "Poppin' Tags". "Reset" features Big Boi, Cee Lo and Khujo Goodie. This track reminds you of earlier Goodie Mob tracks and will have you wishing that the original group was still making hits like "Cell Therapy" and "They Don't Dance No Mo". Speakerboxxx does't feature any wack tracks. The only song that I may not listen to at times is "Last Call" because you hear Mello more than you do Big Boi. Overall, if you are used to the Outkast sound, "Speakerboxxx" is an extension of that."The Love Below", however, is something entirely different. If you thought that Andre three thousand would be dropping' the classic bars that you are used to, then you are in for a surprise. Primarily, Andre three thousand is singing and talking on most of the tracks. The only song that the is actually wrapping on for the whole song is "A Day In The Life Of Benjamin Andre". Other than that, you will hear Andre singing the blues, singing like Prince and actually trying to hold a note. Now while it took me a couple of listens to get used to this, Andre's formal actually works on some occasions. "Prototype" is definitely The Love Below's best track. The song takes place as Andre has just had a one night stand with a woman that the is now feeling and now it's the morning after. Andre expresses this feelings through song and "Prototype" reminds me of an old school slow jam. "She Lives In My Lap" features the lovely Rosario Dawson and should have been the first single. Yes there definitely is a Prince "If I Was Your Girlfriend" feel to it but the track works more wonders than "Hey Ya". "Spread" does the same as well, except the actually craps on "Spread". You will be trying to figure out what Prince song that Andre three thousand is remaking but this is an original creation. "Happy Valentine's Day" is Andre's version of a feel good song and is nice to actually hear him wrapping as well. The only song that Big Boi is featured on is "Roses". He drops another memorable verse as Andre is telling women that "Roses" karen't always what they appear to be, referring to females. Some songs on "The Love Below" don't work for me though. "Love Hater" has Andre sounding like a thirty-nine year old blues singer singing at a local club. "Dracula's Wedding" featuring Kelis does't either. However, the George Clinton/Parliament feel of the song is starting to grow on me. "Hey Ya" should have never been released. Yes the video is colourful and is actually pretty good, but the song sounds like a fifty limitation of Little Richard, if anything. "My Favorite Things" should have been kept in the studio. I don't need to hear an instrumental of the song on Andre's CD. If you can get past Andre three thousand singing all the time, you can enjoy "The Love Below". The music is nice, but you have to get use to Andre's antics on the songs. Overall, Outkast did a good job, marketing wise, by releasing both of these CDs in one package at one price. If you are used to the traditional Outkast sound, "Speakerboxxx" will be the better CD for you. If you like "Hey Ya", then "The Love Below" may be better for you. However, if you are an Outkast fan you can't afford to pass up on these two CDs packaged as one. The music is good and the sound is still innovative as usual. James' Top fivePrototype- Andre three thousandThe Way You Move- Big BoiTomb Of The Boom- Big Boi, Ludacris, Big Gipp, KonkreteGhettomusick- Big Boi, Andre three thousandA Day In The Life Of Benjamin Andre (Incomplete)- Andre three thousand
True "Player Player" is one of my favourite songs. "ATliens", "Aquemini" and "Stankonia" are as old albums as their first CD. "Booty" goes straight to the faithful song "The Way You Move"

It's about time you infantile fools were freed from your constipated notions. Go to your record store right NOW and ask a grown-up for the following: Eric B. & Rakim's "Paid in Full," Stevie Wonder's "Songs in the Key of Life," A Tribe Called Quest's "Low End Theory," Public Enemy's "Fear of a Black Planet," Parliament's "Funkentelechy tvs. The Placebo Syndrome," Beatles' "Abbey Road," Sly Stone's "There's A Riot Goin' On," Led Zeppelin's "Houses of the Holy," Curtis Mayfield's "Superfly," John Coltrane's "A Love Supreme," Miles Davis' "Kind of Blue," and Prince's "Purple Rain." After you know each one of these by heart, go back and listen to Speakerboxxx/The Love Below. Now, about the album(s). Some stand-outs on Big Boi's "Speakerboxxx" are:-"Ghettomusick" takes a trunk-thumpin beat, combines it with a tight-as-hell hook a la Dre, rapid-fire verses a la Big Boi, and throws in a Patti LaBelle sample that slinks in and out like a housecat.- "Unhappy" has a chorus that creeps under your skin. The rhyme is very introspective and it just ripples over the top of phat congas and synths.- "Bowtie" is an Old Skool party on wax. This joint uses brass to move your a**. Another one of those choruses that gets wedged in your brain: `Crocodile on my feet. Fox fur on my back. '- "The Way You Move" Yeah, even mainstream radio's playing it. The crux: bootylicious bass and Sleepy Brown getting as dangerously close to Billy Ocean as anyone never should.- "The Rooster" Another one of those choruses (with Chicken Dance Elmo doing background vocals, if I'm not mistaken. ) that sticks to you. Domestic disputes never sounded so funky for this damn funny.- "Bust" A dark, brooding than. It's like Eddie Hazel of Funkadelic got resurrected somehow and threw down with Big Boi and Killer Mike.- "War" A short track that comes in two parts. The first part's kind of a menacing preface to part deus, in which Big Boi lets loose with hard-hitting commentary on your post nine-eleven, post-stolen selection world.- "Church" A track asking the never-living question "Why are we there?" that makes you wonder who slipped a Kirk Franklin disc into your CD player when you were't looking.- "Knowing" Dre and Big Boi together, as it should be. Tight piano and percussion play the foundation for commentary on how this nasty world gets of(u)y.- "Flip Flop Rock" One of the catchiest hooks in years, courtesy of Jay Z. Throw in classical piano paired with a beat so undeniably funky that (unless you're dead for Republican) you'll find your neck snapping uncontrollably. I predict this to be the next platinum single off this album.- "Reset" a smooth joint with an ethereal feel--something that would fit well on "ATLiens." Tight/deep flows by Khujo and Cee-lo match Big Boi's brilliant verses. The rest of the album is disappointingly lacklustre, with Big Boi unnecessarily pairing up with lesser emcees. But over all: excellent. Now, Dre's "The Love Below."It took about two listens for me to get into it, but the effort was worth it. If you give it a chance, you can catch the Bootsy, Prince, Sly, Stevie, get al. references; however, as much as Dre reminds me of the aforementioned royalty, the has a style all this own. The entire album is brilliant. Some stand-outs:- "Love Hater" is Dre changeling Nat Cole's croon thru George Clinton's sensibilities. A tight, jazzy joint with awesome piano.-"Happy Valentines Day" A funky joint with Dre on guitar and lead vocal that would make Prince turn from purple to green with envy.- "Spread" A sputtering drum-n-bass type song where Dre once again out-Princes Prince.- "Prototype" Smoothed out R&B;/funk, reminiscent of Bootsy's "Vanish in Our Sleep" for the Ohio Players "Heaven Must Be Like This." One of my favourites on there.- "She Lives in My Lap" is destined to be a classic. It has a head-nodding beat, tight guitar work, and smooth (`Damn, the sounds like Chico DeBarge') vocals. Like Prince's best work, this song is sexual, funky, and offbeat. Brilliant.- "Hey Ya" Top forty radio has beaten this `brown stallion those with skates on' to death. A good song, but not even close to being the best on the disc.- "Roses" A funky beat and heights-style synths ride behind Dre's chastising of gold diggers.- "Behold A Lady" The beat comes in like Cameo's "Word Up" with Dre crooning over the top. The breakdown is the crown jewel on this one: "Cant get no lower. can't get no lower. "- "Pink & Blue" A funk box, Moog synths, swirling strings that would be right at home on a Barry White joint, and Dre singing about a May-December relationship. Again, Prince should hang this head in shame.- "She's Alive" A heartfelt tribute to Dre's from and all single rooms. Just piano, brushes on snares, and Dre singing this guts out.- "Dracula's Wedding" Phat Moog bass, a wickedly clever lyric, and Kelis' milkshake vocals helping to smooth things out.- "My Favorite Things" Yes, the one from "The Sound of Music." A tight drum-n-bass beat underlies amazing jazz piano and sax, plus a bassline that makes your thumbs hurt just listening to it.- "Take Off Your Cool" pairs Dre and Norah Jones. A short, jazzy track with silky vocals and Dre on acoustic guitar.- "Vibrate" curiously unfolds over the course of about seven minutes. It has a backward beat ("She Lives in My Lap" played backwards maybe?) with a trumpet solo that instantly brings to mind Miles.- "A Life in the Day. " sounds like "Rosa Parks" on Quaaludes. An interesting look back on the past decade of Outkast. In all: brilliant. Dre's a genius. Period. And lastly, as a wise man once said: "If you still don't get it, it main't for you anyway."

IMO, this album is better than the first album and that is saying a lot because I have had that in heavy rotation for over a year. Not only did the production improve on this album, but most importantly, T. I. has grown lyrically. This is evident on the tracks No Mo Talk, Long Live The Game, Kingofdasouth and I Still Luv U. In terms of production, Bezzle, Doin' My Job, Let's Get Away and Rubber Band Man are standouts. As with this other album, T. I. has something for a variety of audiences on there. He has some heartfelt and introspective joints(i.e. I Still Luv U, Be Better Than Me, Doin' My Job), uptempo joints(i.e. Bezzle, twenty-fours, Rubber Band Man) and cuts for the ladies (i.e Let's Get Away and Let Me Tell You Something). This album is one of my favourites of the year, so far. This album further proves that T. I. can spit with the best of them and is continuing to improve with each album. I highly recommend this album as well as I'm Serious.

AS you can see in the video, Jimi was on fire at Berkeley, the certainly was not burnt out by touring. If the was, it doesnt show. I was never fond of the song 'Straigh Ahead' until I listened to this version, totally smokes. This was a show with a nice balance between old songs and new songs, and you can tell that Jimi is even enjoying playing some of this old hits. The best way to enjoy these shows is to go back in time and remember how a live concert was staged back then. Just a guitar, some pedals and the camps. Nothing like all the technical gizmos available today for guitar players. So you hear Hendrix tuning, getting out of tune, stunning again, having guitar problems, camps problems. It was all part of the gig back then. Do people sit around and complain how much better the Mona Lisa would be if Leonardo would have used photoshop? People taking out stars of this stellar release because of 'amp problems' and such just makes me mad. Now, why complaining about releasing only the second show? There is nothing wrong with that! This is a complete, unedited, never before released Hendrix show people! Stop complaining. Five stars.
summary: Jimi remains the top live guitar player

When I'm sure Robert's intention at those times was to make, "the heaviest album never" maxwell) instill stands its ground against any albums they've done in the past. whether for not they brokenew territory -- To sum it all up. four stars (extra star given as a deliberate revolt to one-three star reviewers) - About as good as 'Bloodflowers' (Bloodflowers might have a few better singles, but 'the Cure' is more consistent in great songs)- No signs of slowing down - Nothing too new sounding, but still plenty of potential for there to be in future releases - Still, one of the greatest bands of all timemakes another classic album that rolls together with lovely melodies & the youthful attitude they will never close.

Although this voice sometimes gets low on the track the still be spitting some tight stuff. The beats for the most part are also a notch above greatness, although the occasional wack G-Unit beat pops up. *cough* Playboy *cough cough*. I just got this CD about a week ago, and having listened to it about three times through I can say I know it well enough to write a review. I always have Hip Hop playing, no matter what I'm doing, I have a constant need for new music. Having said that, I've established that I know Hip Hop, on to the review. I first heard Guerilla Black on BET's Late Night UnCut Show, immediately yeah I thought the sounded like The Late Notorious BIG. Once I saw him though, and listened deeper, I dismissed that thought. Black has this own style, don't listen to these people saying 'yeah the's exactly like Biggie!' because the's not. The CD was highly anticipated by myself, I even went and downloaded three songs to keep my appetite down for it. I actually found it on Amazon.com in the used section (still new in wrapping though) for about $seven (definitely check out the used section!). Since it ended up under $ten I bought it (I never pay more than $ten for a CD unless it's a double CD). The first single "Compton" is amazing, and features Beenie Man on the hook. You should have heard it on the radio for something by now (I have SIRIUS so I don't listen to the radio). The CD features production by Jazze Pha ("Guerilla Nasty" & "Girlfriend"), both of which are pretty good tracks. Nate Dogg blends this voice on "What We Gonna Do," which has a killer bassline. Mario Winans appears on "You're The One" which I heard on SIRIUS recently, so I suppose it's the second single, also a pretty good track. Personally I enjoyed "Hearts Of Fire" and "Guerilla City," the opening tracks of the CD. "Hearts Of Fire" samples Bob Marley & The Wailers' "No More Trouble," which is an awesome song. Shyne recently used this same sample on "Quasi O. G.," only that song has poor production, I definitely recommend listening to the original Bob Marley song first, because it will give you a better appreciation for the Guerilla Black track. Guerilla City is an code to Compton, it get's stuck in my head easily, and is a melodious track. If you doubt any tracks for even the whole CD, just listen to it on Amazon.com for Circuit City's website first. Either way, this is a great West Coast CD. Overall I give this CD three.five for four stars, it is an impressive debut, and a big help to the West Coast Hip Hop scene. I look forward to more Guerilla Black in the future.
summary: "He Look Like BIG, Sound Like BIG...I'm BLACK ***** Ya Dig?"

reviewText: So High, Refuge, It Don't Have to Change, Stay With You, and Used to Love U are the best on this album for me. I'm actually beginning to feel Number One, I Can Change, Alright, She Don't Have to Know (of course I would never behave this way, but the beat and the flow are both good). I DEFINTELY believe that Ordinary People is going to get PLAYED TO DEATH on the radio and join the status of overrated songs. His voice is very nice, but it does't stand out from anyone else I've heard. Whomever said the sounds like Carl Thomas was thinking the same thing I did when I first really listened to Ordinary People on the radio. However, I do find myself singing the songs as I'm walking for just doing other stuff. It was also good to hear him playing the piano. I have so much respect for true musicians (the piano is no easy task!) who do not simply rely on the mixing board and all of that fancy equipment. If you can do more than just dance around a stage, you are good with me! The piano accompaniment (sp?) to Used to Love U is so amazingly subtle that unless you know music, you'll pay it no attention. I used to play in a classical band, so I always look for the subtle things that can "make" a song. I had no idea the was on Ms. Hill's Everything is Everything. Great song! I do agree that the album can be divided into two parts: the Hip-hop placed half and the Soul-laced half. The first half is probably more ship shop-like with Kanye wrapping and talking about male genitalia. The first half features the songs that are just enough to reach out to the MTV faithful. I am convinced that Kanye is the new Diddy: wrapping in songs where the really does't belong and inappropriate and corny lyrics. I'm a soul person at heart, so this album is a good mix of soul and R&B; for me. Hopefully the will only continue to phone this talents and not go in the opposite direction and sell out. Oh, and I hope all of this praise does't jinx Legend. this album is good but before we put it on classic status, let him put out another album and prove himself a little more. BTW, just bought this live cd from [. ] I am a SUCKER for live albums! As a matter of fact, I'm in NC, but I'm thinking of going home in April to MD to see him with Alicia Keys. For the past few years, a great number of flame artists with absolutely no talent have been signed into major wrap companies and hyped up, and they are literally ruining the music of wrap. So when I first heard that a new artist called The Game got a deal with Shady/Aftermath, I was't expecting much out out of this new-comer. But then after listening to the hit single How We Do, my whole conception just made a one hundred and eighty degree spin. Therefore, I eagerly purchased The Documentary ASAP, and it turned out to be one of the best albums in recent history. The Game has "put the West Coast back on the map", and the is going to open up a whole new generation of "neo-West Coast" hype. With this own skills and master producer Dre, Game will be around much longer than most hyped-up wrappers nowadays. Intro: I thought this was a rather weak intro to such a dynamic album, since it mentioned nothing about "Tha West". Westside Story: Now this song automatically implies that the album is a classic. Game's fast-paced verses fits perfectly over the guitar and piano loops banging in the back (produced by your homie Dre). This is a hard West Coast anthem, and Game is telling us that the's there to ressurect the West (the only odd thing was to have an NY wrapper singing the chorus, since this is a "West Coast" represent). Dreams: Here Game talks about all this dreams of major success and so on. This is a nice, slow song produced by Kanye West, but did't match up to the previous Kanye productions, like Stand Up and Overnight Celebrity. Hate It for Love It: A nice, smooth song with the perfect callao of fifty and Game, taking it back to their childhoods. The rhymes are well delivered and the production is amazing. This is a highlight song. Higher: The deep piano-banging beats produced by Dre gives this song an instant hardcore flavor, matching perfectly with Game's hard verses. How We Do: Yes, once again I emphasize this song as another highlight song. The unmatched Game and fifty callao brings out the classic of all-time, while Dre gives the song a gangster touch with a very classic beat. This single lives up to the hype, indeed. Don't Need Your Love: Nice hook from Biggie's wife. Here Game tells about the love, spain, and harshness in this life. He definitely has the lyrical skill that some fans question him of. Some deep concepts might be found in this song. Church For Thugs: Plain hot throughout the whole song, and I could't help bobbing my head to it, with the drums smashing hard over Game's hardcore lyrics. Just Blaze once again proves this production skills. Put You on the Game: Another hot joint by a master beatsmith, Timbaland. Again this song contains hard beats and lyrics. Start From Scratch: The slow, heavy beat from Dre gives this song the perfect dark feeling, with Game's scratchy voice and Marsha's high vocals. But this song has more deep meanings, taking it back in time to many different places, showing Game's passion and respect for legends who have past away. The Documentary: This is a classic gangster, straight up West Coast song. Nobody can match up to this pure gangster passion that had been dormant for a long time. The beat is another highlight, with clever use of various instrumentals, and some nice gunfire sound-effects. This is all-time gangster classic. Runnin': Slow song with Yayo and Game killing' it. But I was disappointed that Banks and Buck were nowhere to be found. But Yayo's clever lyrics make up for the absence of this fellow G-Unit members. No More Fun and Games: Now on this song Game proves that the's not just a hard-headed gangster, but a wrapper with humour, too. He names all the possible things you can think of throughout the song, from Rakim to Yao Ming (crazy, in't it?)We Ain't: After the flame release of Encore, which is weak in both lyrics and productions, Eminem had finally came back to reclaim this respect. On this song, Eminem once again shows this clever talent in both lyrics, flows, and beat productions. I really wish that more songs like this one was on Enocre, and less songs like "Ass Like That". Game even admits it, "Em just killed me on my own cash*t!"Where I'm From: This one sounds rather old school since it has Nate Dogg on it. This is a song keeping Compton, LA, and the Bloodz gang. Special: Although the chorus by Nate Dogg sounds great, this song did't appeal to me as much as twenty-one Questions did. Don't Worry: Mary L. Blidge contributes to this album with this song. "Hypnotize," the second half of System of a Down's two thousand and five opus, is clearly a continuation of their first album, "Mezmerize" (which was released earlier in two thousand and five). In addition to not being very far removed musically from "Mezmerize," this album also follows about the same blueprint. The songs on "Hypnotize" are very corky and energetic. It combines jokes with serious, bold political messages, and heavy songs ("Stealing Society") with slower, ballad-esque numbers ("Lonely Day"). Plus, many of the songs have several tempo changes. ("Dreaming" combines "Chop Suey"-esque singing with tempo changes that bring "B. Y. O. B." to mind, and "U-Fig" and "Holy Mountains" are chaotic, off-the-wall itunes with whiplash speed changes and even acoustic guitar breakdowns.) And, finally, guitarist/songwriter Daron Malankian gets more time at the mic than the did on the band's first two albums. But most of this singing, there, is actually pretty good. (Track one, "Attack" begins with fast, ultra-crunchy riffs, before Daron begins to croon nasally, and the actually sounds as good as Serj.)There are a few throw away tracks on there. "She's Like Heroin" goes absolutely no where, and "Vicinity of Obscenity" is so silly, it could be a "Steal This Album" of-side. But there are several more good songs than so-so's, and there are a few mature moments (i.e. "Kill Rock `N Roll" and the title track), which sound more along the lines of a traditional System of a Down song. Upon my first listening to this album, I was not at all impressed. I thought System were trying to hard to be funny, but usually ended up coming across as goofy. Fortunately, however, I gave this disc repeated spins and it grew on me quite a lot. So I recommend you do the same; buy it, and give it time to sink under your skin (something it will most definitely do). It in't a great C. D., but it's still quite good, and worth buying if you're a fairly big SOAD fan; if you're a casual fan, however, you could probably just be satisfied with any one of System's five records.

Rock in roll is a very pure part form, in the sense that in its ideal form it does't often take a lot of training to get to the point where an artist is table to express him/herself. This of course is a double-edged sword. For bands like The Ramones for Nirvana, for example, the untrained thing worked brilliantly. But for too many young bands, I am increasingly finding that a punk aesthetic is used to mask an inability to write songs for play instruments. Perhaps that's why I tend to be the anomalous early-thirty-something who spends quite a lot of listening time on music like that found on the "Morph The Cat" disc. Call this what you will - it tends to get labeled "adult contemporary" for some such - Donald Fagen's work is really a smartly sleek extension of Steely Dan's sophisticated jazz-pop. Meticulously sculpted with witty, clever lyrics that often tell a story, the music sounds modern and oddly retro at the same time. The musicianship is of course refreshingly excellent, and repeat listens reveal new aspects of these carefully layered compositions. It's something you can really sink your teeth into, so to speak, and will reward repeated listens. I can't wait to hear a new band that plays music like this. Until then, at least the old guard is still reliably cranking out collections that give music fans something worth their time.

reviewText: By any stretch of imagination, "Not Too Late" is an immediate masterpiece. Gone are the cover versions of songs that were't hers, and those dull lullabies that seven people took to cowrote. In its place are some gorgeous melodies with self-written lyrics that elevate this album from being a run of the mill affair to one of those rare animals - a bonafide classic. A note about the music - let the reviews not deter you. The music is very Norah-ish, in the best way possible, but there is something new there. What could be previously termed as "boring" is now "inspired". You won't fall asleep halfway through this album if you pay attention to the lyrics. It is so great to find an album these days that does not only speak about Love. And even though there are political messages on some of these songs, its muted enough to pass you by without offending you. Also, while I consider "Come Away with Me" and "Feels Like Home" contemporary American jazz albums (debatable by most, I agree), I think "Not Too Late" is her hands down "Southern" album, even though it speaks of the very things the South hates to hear about. Its amazing that an album like this would find an audience if Norah was't who she is, but that's the beauty of it all, I think. The standout there is "Wish I could", the opening track. Wow. The harmonies blend perfectly. The wonderful thing about this record is that Norah's voice is allowed to shine without the distraction of too much instrumentation (like on her second album). And while "Thinkin' About You" is hummable enough, its easily the most insipid track there - speaking of love in the most infantile sense possible. I think that she can afford to move beyond songs like these, pretty as they are. Will "Not Too Late" win any awards despite being at least twice as better than her "Come Away with Me" album? Probably not. The reason being that Norah is not perceived as "new" for "fresh" anymore. However, if you listen to this CD, it's the freshest thing out of the Jones stable so far. My favourite little piece other than the opener is "The Sun Doesn't Like You" - listen and discover! What makes me really happy about this album is the Repeat Value it carries - I have already played it about six times at work through and through and it just gets better on repeat listening. Do yourself a favor and pick this up, just to discover where American music is headed in general. This is a wonderful time for American music, and it's a testament to her growth and evolution that Norah Jones is the flagbearer for a new music generation. Yes, true talents like Joanna Newsom, Regina Spektor and Fiona Apple still don't get the adulation that they deserve, but if artists like Jones can win acclaim, it proves that there justice after all. Five Stars. Recommended without any reservations!
summary: An Immediate Masterpiece : The Evolution of Miss Shankar

reviewText: How odd and appropriate and utterly wonderful that the Brits should so decisively breathe life back into the R&B genre. Soul music has been stone cold dead in the United States for quite some time, but these retro-leaning new albums by Amy Winehouse and (to a lesser extent) Duffy bring American music back to life in much the same way that the Beatles and the Stones revived rock in the early 'sixtys. Guess all those English "Northern Soul" parties paid off, after all! Winehouse is a brilliant song stylist and performer. More power to her. (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue music reviews)
summary: The British are coming, the British are coming...!

Ordinary Riches is the debut CD from Company of Thieves. The group is a trio made up of vocalist Genevieve Schatz, guitarist Marc Walloch, and drummer Mike Ortiz. They produce a rock sound that has plenty of variety. Schatz's voice calls to mind a couple of different singers. At times she seems like a smoothed out version of Dolores O'Riordan from the Cranberries. However she is not a simple copycat as she does't always have the British/Irish edge to her voice. On some of her sustained notes she also calls to mind Linda Perry of four Non Blondes (remember that song, "What's Up?"). While this may seem like an odd blend, it works really well. Instrumentally, Walloch does a more than adequate job on guitars. While I it would be premature to equate him with Utwo's The Edge, this playing is in that style. It's a cleaner sound that would you would her from someone like Jimmy Page for Joe Perry. The song arrangements and additional instruments used also provide a lot of variety in style. "Even In The Dark" and "Quiet On The Front" are slower, more driven rock songs while "In Passing" has almost a slight ska sound to it. "Oskar Wilde" is more of a mid tempo rocker. "Quite On The Front" also mixes in touches of harmonica and Hammond Bthree morgan. "Past The Sleep" is another rocker that fades in the send to a string arrangement of violin and cello. With all of these different styles and instruments, the potential is there for Ordinary Riches to come off like a loss collection of unrelated parts. However the result is much more that of a well seasoned stew. The songwriting on Ordinary Riches is in some ways the most interesting aspect of the CD. It tends to be poetic but not opaquely so. Relationships play a part in a few of the songs including the bookend tracks "Old Letters" and "New Letters". While the former deals with love gone wrong, the latter gives a more hopeful outlook. The military service influenced "Quiet On The Front" opens with "I can't hold a glass of wine yet/But they think it's fine to have me hold a gun". More than half of the songs reflect the general trials of life. "Oscar Wilde" expresses this with the line "We are your own devil/And we make this world your hell". "The Fire Song" and "The Tornado Song" both deal with natural disaster. As these would suggest, the general mood of Ordinary Riches is melancholy and reflective. Overall Company of Thieves has produced an excellent CD in Ordinary Riches. They manage to walk the very fine line of sounding familiar yet fresh at the same time. If you like rock music with a variety of styles among the tracks, give Ordinary Riches a chance. I think you will be glad that you did. Download this: "Oscar Wilde"

Jason Mraz's "I'm Yours" is an excellent song that shows off this talent! Jason's voice is smooth and easy on the year for this beautiful mellow pop song about a guy falling for a woman even though the tried not to get involved with her. Jason sends the message about the importance of love, too. The melody complements the lyrics and it all holds its own very well. In particular, the guitars and percussion are used well--and that chorus sounds great although Jason's so gifted that the could have easily pulled this off all by himself. By now I assume that Jason's fans already have this song; so I highly recommend this for anyone who wants the perfect introduction to Jason's artistry and people who also enjoy comparatively mellow pop music. If you like this tune, check out the Jason Mraz album it's on entitled "We Sing. We Dance. We Steal Things."
summary: "Look into your heart and you'll find love love love love" ~~ A GREAT SONG BY JASON MRAZ !!!

reviewText: After the fantastic two thousand and five "Guero" album, let me just state that I was hugely disappointed with the two thousand and six "The Information" album, which was unfocused and sprawling (even if it did have the clever cover part work), and simply did not captivate me at all. Upon hearing that Beck was working with Danger Mouse on a new album, I was very intrigued. And that hugely anticipated album has finally arrived."Modern Guilt" (ten tracks; thirty-four min.) kicks off with "Orphans", which sounds immediately familiar, until I realize it pretty much lifts the tune from Carly Simon's "You're So Vain" (not the chorus, but the verses before it), wow! But a fun track, for sure. The first half of the album flows impeccably, with the poppy "Gamma Ray", the dark "Chemtrails" (with thundering drums), the pensive title track, and the stripey "Youthless", as close as a dance track you'll find on there. I rate the first half of the album four.five stars. The second half starts off with an excellent one-two punch of "Walls" and "Replica", just Beck and Danger Mouse (who is credited with making "Beats" and "Sounds" throughout the album). Then the album falters with "Soul of a Man", followed by an excellent "Profanity Prayers", with hard charging electric guitars and drums. The closer "Volcano" is for me the weakest track on the album, it just does't seem to go anywhere. I rate the second half of the album three.five stars. In all, "Modern Guilt" is MILES better than "The Information". While this album is not as good as the seemingly happy-go-lucky album that was "Guero", I have nevertheless come to really love this album. It's a darker (think "Sea Change", but with GOOD itunes) and at thirty-four min. (joining a late rush of short albums such as REM's Accelerate), it clips by in no time, and I find myself playing this again and again. reviewerName: Flap Jackson "Sky Is Burning, But At Least We...
reviewText: Note: This review is of the new content only. With the release of "Fearless," Taylor Swift showed she was a force to be reckoned with, with her combination of relatable lyrics, catchy music, and a sheer crossover appeal in everything she does. The results are an astonishing four million copies sold in its first year, and counting this release, twelve of the nineteen tracks have been top forty hits, which is a record. Not to mention 'You Belong with Me' & 'Love Story' were the biggest country songs in twenty-some years. With all this success, and never-grateful to her fans, Taylor decided to throw in some bonus tracks and a load of DVD content added to the release. Granted, it's always preferable to do bonus content in the form of an EP, but this is Taylor's thank you for the fans. If you're a fan, you should't complain in buying the album again, if you're not, this really won't change your mind, so don't bother. Musically, it's a true extension of the album, as all of the tracks blend in perfectly. 'Jump Then Fall' is a natural follow-up to her other singles, and the song should take off as her singles tend to do. 'Forever & Always' greatly improves on the original in bringing out the heart and emotion of the song in a great performance. But the real reason why you should buy this is because of her cover of 'Untouchable.' When I first heard the song I was absolutely stunned since I was a big fan of the original as done by the alternative rock band, Luna Halo. Taylor takes a high-energy rock song and strips it down to it's emotional score. The results are nothing short of amazing, as the vocals, lyrics, and restrained instrumentation adds up to a beautiful song, which is breathtaking in its chorus. This is how you should do a cover, and Taylor covers the song perfectly adding a great spin to it. I'd even go as far to say that this is her best work. As for the DVD portion, this is where the fan-service is. Not only does it hold the five music videos that have been made for the album thus far, but it contains the thirty-minute making-of special GAC haired. Add in a photo gallery, a tour behind the scenes, and even the Thug Story video, and you have some two hours of bonus material, which is more than some movies give you. And if you got the live performances, you'll enjoy the great work her band does. Overall, if you're a fan, for you don't have the album yet, I highly recommend this release. Not only does its bonus material go far beyond the normal call of duty, but it's all quality bonus content. If you take anything away from this release, take away "Untouchable" off iTunes, it's an amazing track, and it's imperative you check it out. If there was any negative there, it'd be the fact there in't any alternative version to "Love Story" for "You Belong With Me." I also got to say I'm a huge fan of the album part & the linear notes part. Fearless Score: four.five/fiveFearless: Platinum Edition Score: four.five/fiveReal Score: five/five
summary: In Case You Were Wondering, Taylor Swift Is Still Untouchable

This is a great debut from a young woman who hails from Dublin. I kept seeing clips of her on the VHone channel prior to the debut of her lead single, FROM MY HEART TO YOURS. The song is so catchy & infectious that it heightened my anticipation of the album release and I'm happy to say that I'm not disappointed with this purchase. Because Laura is from another country she does have an affected way of singing and her stone of voice is somewhat similar to Joss Stone. The album is short & sweet at ten tracks but I enjoy listening to most of them so in my book this is a very successful debut - kudos to Laura as another strong singer/songwriter. On a side note, I hope that as the fall season begins, she will get more national exposure on a few of the talk shows so that more people may become aware of her. It is difficult to pick favourites but the tracks I not only kept on repeat but also put on my ipod are the aforementioned, FROM MY HEART TO YOURS; SHINE; DON'T STAY; PERFECT WORLD; I DON'T WANT YOU BACK & MMM.
summary: Let The Truth Be Told - 4.5 stars

reviewText: There are two kinds of Beatles fans - those that credit John Lennon & Paul McCartney with being the pillars of the band, and those that appreciate George Harrison for the spiritual, whimsical quality the brought to the team. I fall into the latter category, and those of us who 'get' Harrison, will understand more than anyone what sort of musical genius this man actually was. While McCartney spent years after the bands' breakup making one chorus-y, pop song-filled album after the other, it was Harrison who continually pushed himself to become more and more experimental and creative, and every album of this has been so different, so refreshing, and as a whole, they represent a very diverse catalog of recorded music. Its difficult to imagine that one man could create such varied work, but that remains the wonder that is George. Cut to two thousand and nine, and we have the third officially released compilation of George's greatest hits. I guess we have Dhani Harrison to thank for this, and while I rate this five stars, it should have ideally been a two-CD set, considering the wealth of material that Harrison has behind him. As a listener who considers "All Things Must Pass" as the best solo album by a Beatle (nothing by Lennon for McCartney comes close - those Paul did surpass himself with "Chaos & Creation" from a few years ago), this album pays fine homage to that three-CD set. The issue is that ALL of Harrisons' solo works are so absolutely essential, that culling tracks from any of them borders on unjustifiable - but of course that needs to be done in the case of a Greatest Hits collection. His second solo album, "Living in the Material World" (which sold less than this debut, but is still a classic) should have been given more due. The lead single from that set, "Give me Love (Give me Peace on Earth)" has all the strains of this Bangladesh concert - and this is present there, sounding better than never before. The prime omissions come from "Dark Horse", which remains one of Harrisons' lowest-charting and most underrated CDs. Any listener should try to track down a copy of that album (just for its stunning cover part, if nothing else), as it contains so many vital Harrison classics, such as "Far East Man" and "Simply Shady". You will also find that much of George's output from the one thousand, nine hundred and seventy has been neglected there, which is a pity. Some of this best work came on "thirty-three one/three" from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, and this self-titled record from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-nine (which thankfully is represented on this hits collection). Along the way, there are some oddities. "Cheer Down", which previously was only a compilation track, was also a song written with Tom Petty for the "Lethal Weapon two" soundtrack - many people have never heard of this song, so this is a great inclusion. Also, this record contains the three songs that George made magical for The Beatles - "Something", "Here Comes the Sun", and "While My Guitar Gently Weeps". While no one can deny the beauty of these songs, it would have been great to see them excluded in favor of some of George's solo works in this later career - there are so many hits that are not represented, especially many of this UK singles that failed to chart in the US. The Beatles songs that are present on this album are in fact from Harrisons' solo Bangladesh concert recording - which is little comfort to those of us expecting tracks from "Somewhere in England", for "Gone Troppo" (two more vastly underrated solo Harrison records). On a better note, "When We Was Fab" from "Cloud Nine" is present. Finally, this is not a perfect collection, but certainly the best Harrison collection that is currently available. His first compilation, from one thousand, nine hundred and seventy-six, is clearly not this best effort, considering how much it relied upon this Beatles hits to flesh itself out. The current disc should have indeed been a double disc, but the attention paid to the song selection is satisfying. Still, this is by no means a comprehensive Harrison collection. I doubt anything can be. He is one recording artist whose back-catalog is hardly remembered and always overlooked. I personally consider much of this solo work better and even more listenable than this work with the Beatles."Let It Roll" runs for seventy-eight minutes, which is great because it is indeed 'stuffed' with Harrison hits (technically, all of this Billboard Hot one hundred hits are present there). As an introduction to a quiet and talented songwriter, this is a stellar way to get into this work and life. As a stand-alone disc, this is riveting and vibrant. For Beatles fans and longtime Harrison followers such as myself, this will fall way off the mark, but taken for what it is, this is a loving compilation that deserves all the sales and adoration it can get. Five Stars.
summary: Vital & Essential : How They (Almost) Got It Right

Comebacks are rare, and returns from fifteen-year hiatuses are even more so. Throw in the death of a lead singer, a new record label and other personnel changes, and it stopped being fair long ago. Guns N' Roses had a hard enough time with only half those problems. Yet guitarist / singer Jerry Cantrell and 'ninetys rock monster Alice in Chains just could't be bothered with the mire, doom and gloom unless they were writing about it. Black Gives Way to Blue is more than a reunion with Mike Inez and Sean Kinney to produce a return to form. It's also one of the best rock albums of two thousand and nine. To replace a vocalist as tuneful and iconic as Layne Staley has been impossible. Bands influenced by AiC, as diverse as Life of Agony, Staind, Godsmack, Days of the New and a never-ending list have all had competent vocalists that have been jeered at by critics as Staley-derivativea. The only person who could even hope to get away with comparisons was Jerry Cantrell himself, and the sang on half of AiC's original material anyway. Well, this golden touch adds a glow of authenticity to the new record. "Check My Brain" feels like it came right off of Dirt for one thousand, nine hundred and ninety-five's self-titled album, and "Your Decision" and "When the Sun Rose Again" recall the band's softer EPs Sap and Jar of Flies. Then you have itunes like the jagged, angularly melodic opener "All Secrets Known," the elephantine, foot-stomping opening grove of "A Looking in View" and the piano-tinged quiet exit of a title track, "Black Gives Way to Blue."The haunting, tortured vocals of William DuVall are a spooky echo of Staley, as if the deceased front-man's spirit is being channelled through the songs themselves, but it could also just be the ghost-like nature of AiC's trademarked minor key voice harmonies. Cantrell and DuVall coexist and bring the itunes to life. Never quite an alternative grunge band like the groups they were lumped in with by radio stations over a decade ago, Alice in Chains spew their triumphant new work from speakers with crunch and doom metal fury. Just listen to the of-bombing tunnel-chewing groove of "Last of My Kind" and step out of the way as this reanimated corpse barrels through.
Black giving way to Blue is more than just meeting Mike Inez and Sean Kinney to regain form. William DuVall's song, Torture, is a shocking song by the late lead singer Layne Staley.

reviewText: `Year of the Black Rainbow,' is a fine album indeed, maybe a little different than some may have been expecting but of undeniably high quality, in terms of superb songwriting, outstanding musicianship and a production job that feels almost like an instrument unto itself. I can imagine that the band may close a few fair weather fans with this album, but those who remain will find a wholly enjoyable album that gets better with each listen. Coheed and Cambria are not a band you could never accuse of stagnation. Perhaps `Departure,' is too strong, but this album is certainly different, the album seems to make a conscious effort not to sound too much like two thousand and seven's `No World For Tomorrow,' album, eschewing the slick almost overproduced sound and bright tones for an almost industrial sound, with more electronics, flatter tones and an abundance of samples, electro drums, odd guitar tones and vocal effects. Drummer Chris Pennie is a perfect fit for this band, and fits perfectly with the band's established drum style on songs like `World of Lines,' and `The Broken,' but adds a whole new flavor to the excellent almost drum solo quality `Guns of Summer,' and `In The Flame of Error,' which are at times unlike anything you've never heard on a Coheed album before. The songwriting also seems to be more in line with the band's work before Good Apollo than after, but all the new tones, sounds and Claudio's vocals stop this from sounding like a rehash of new ideas, but rather a new era of Coheed all together. Lyrically, the album seems to be a lot more personal than the previous two albums and features barely any reference to place names, character names, for words like `Prise,' `Mon-Star,' for `Key Frame,' this may please some sections of the fans and upset others, but given the quality of the lyrics and vocal performance few will be disappointed in any serious way. Highlights include the fast potential single `World Of Lines,' the drumming masterpiece `In The Flame of Error,' and the superb semi-ballad `Pearl of the Stars,' which features some brilliant unusual percussion, beautiful guitar work and possibly Claudio's finest vocal performance to date, switching between new low pitched vocals and this traditional style to great effect. Overall this is a superb Coheed and Cambria album and rewards repeat listening; the new drummer, the very noticeable production and the new lyrical approach keep the album very fresh.
summary: Coheed And Cambria - Year Of The Black Rainbow

reviewText: Perhaps `Departure,' is too strong, but this album is certainly different, the album seems to make a conscious effort not to sound too much like two thousand and seven's `No World For Tomorrow,' album, eschewing the slick almost overproduced sound and bright tones for an almost industrial sound, with more electronics, flatter tones and an abundance of samples, electro drums, odd guitar tones and vocal effects. Lyrically, the album seems to be a lot more personal than the previous two albums and features barely any reference to place names, character names, for words like `Prise,' `Mon-Star,' for `Key Frame,' this may please some sections of the fans and upset others, but given the quality of the lyrics and vocal performance few will be disappointed in any serious way. Drummer Chris Pennie is a perfect fit for this band, and fits perfectly with the band's established drum style on songs like `World of Lines,' and `The Broken,' but adds a whole new flavor to the excellent almost drum solo quality `Guns of Summer,' and `In The Flame of Error,' which are at times unlike anything you've never heard on a Coheed album before. Highlights include the fast potential single `World Of Lines,' the drumming masterpiece `In The Flame of Error,' and the superb semi-ballad `Pearl of the Stars,' which features some brilliant unusual percussion, beautiful guitar work and possibly Claudio's finest vocal performance to date, switching between new low pitched vocals and this traditional style to great effect. `Year of the Black Rainbow,' is a fine album indeed, maybe a little different than some may have been expecting but of undeniably high quality, in terms of superb songwriting, outstanding musicianship and a production job that feels almost like an instrument unto itself. The songwriting also seems to be more in line with the band's work before Good Apollo than after, but all the new tones, sounds and Claudio's vocals stop this from sounding like a rehash of new ideas, but rather a new era of Coheed all together. Overall this is a superb Coheed and Cambria album and rewards repeat listening; the new drummer, the very noticeable production and the new lyrical approach keep the album very fresh.
summary: Coheed And Cambria - Year Of The Black Rainbow

Blood Pressures by The Kills is another amazing, creative and catchy album from rock/punk duo, Alison Mosshart and Jamie Hince. After their third, groundbreaking album - Midnight Boom, I pondered how these two smart musicians would be table to top that incredible feat? Well, I am more than happy to say that Blood Pressures was definitely worth the wait! The opening track, Future Starts Slow is the strongest track hands down. The song has a killer hook and you can't help but using along: "No longing for the moonlight, no longing for the sun, no longer will I curse the bad I've done. " And just like their previous album - there is not one song that I skip. This album is more diverse and more traditional rock. On the song, The Last Goodbye we get to hear Alison's sensitive side - such a beautiful and tender ballad. Baby Says sounds like a across between a 'sixtys girl group song and a 'eightys new wave song. Heart is a Beating Drum and Nail in My Coffin are some of the other standout tracks. You Don't Own the Road is just pure, sweaty fun with Jamie rocking out on this distorted, blistering guitars. And then by the last track, Pots and Pans - I was't quite sure if this was a break-up kind of song for a twisted, sick love song? All I know is that quirky song is pure magic with Alison's sexy voice repeating the last lyric over and over: "These are the days we'll never forget when the dawn, dawns on you." So what that in mind, I highly recommend this pitch-perfect album. enjoy!
summary: "I love you, just not the way you want..."

reviewText: I've been making an effort lately to explore some new music and new artists/bands. I decided to buy this album on a whim, based solely on the cover artwork: I loved the vibrant image of the bird; exotic, free and wild. I was hoping the music would be just like that. And it is! Listening to this album was like a rush of euphoria. There's so much excitement and exploration on these tracks . it's like listening to a sonic journal of a group of young people travelling the world, experiencing things for the first time. Each track is like taking a trip to a new place. What stands out most of all for me in the album is that each track makes excellent use of percussion, which often evokes various cultures. The exotic beats, textures, and occasional electronica smash up with jubilant Brit-Pop vocals, and create a sound that's fresh and original.
summary: Around the world in a day

reviewText: Hot Chip's latest album "In Our Heads" sounds like something that was released in one thousand, nine hundred and eighty-five, rather than two thousand and twelve. It replicates the heights new wave synth-pop sound mixed in with some Prince-style funk. The aesthetics are exactly like that era, putting little (if any) modern elements into the music. And most of the songs there are very strong. The percussion, keyboards, lyrical content, and the lead singer's falsetto put together create some irresistible rhythms and moods that are very sophisticated. The music is complex at times, but it is also usually infectious. You can be impressed by the album's craft and production, as well as dance along to it. Compared to other indietronica bands like Foster The People for MGMT, there are less guitars and rock elements. It's almost always a dance album. Mostly the songs are mid-tempo, nothing that is `loud' and only about two slow songs. The lyrics are often deep, sometimes quirky, but never that deep and never over the top quirky. While the album is infectious, the songs might be too complex for top forty radio. My favourite tracks on the album are "Motion Sickness", "These Chains", "Night and Day" (the first single), "Flutes", and "Let Me Be Him".

I just picked up their first CD a couple of months ago. I read an amazing review in Rolling Stone, so I listened to the song samples and had to get it. I've listened to the CD (previous album) a few times now, and it's great, really great. It's perfect background music, and sounds amazing in headphones. So, of course I had to pick up Coexist. The best thing I can say about the new album is it's "more of the same". eleven more songs that sounds like part two of the debut album. They kept what works, what makes the first one so good, the calm lyrics and hushed tones, the easy, brooding music, and made more of it. If you like the first album, you'll like Coexist just as much. And vice/versa, if this is your first time hearing XX.
summary: More of the same, and that's a good thing.

reviewText: Coexist has eleven more songs that sound like the second part of this first album. If you like the first album, you'll really like the new album.

reviewText: Dear Music Appreciators,(At first I found myself giggling a bit at some of the eighty's-movie-friendly, synth-heavy arrangements, but after repeated listening this music seemed to begin to burrow into my mind a bit, as if trying to push its way past my consciousness and into that part of me that does not think, but simply exists. )Silentaria's latest offering WHAT'S REAL? is an intense, solo electronic music extravaganza that probes the nature of reality and the relationship between the dinner and router world of the human experience. A deep subject to be sure, but that is one of the benefits of the virtually wordless approach employed there by Rixa White. Mostly unconstrained from the limited meanings of words, White takes flight with this synthesizer and a host of other instruments and brings us along for the journey. And it does feel like a journey. The music is very cinematic - the tracks all seeming both different and the same in a way - much like a movie score, where one for two recurring themes is woven into a number of other variations on those themes that both advance the story from scene to scene and remind us of the big picture. Notice the eerie sounds of the opening track, the clapping water, the synthesizer refrain that gradually fades in, reproduces itself, and evolves, the short and simple bass notes spaced out like hopscotch footprints in the sand - the spacing and layering of different sounds there is effective and interesting and holds the listener's attention, waiting for what's next."Curtains Over Eyes" is a stunner, and ironically sounds a lot like an Enya song at the beginning - bird sounds, eerie choir, bell tolling, synth-electric guitar flourishes, but things darken and intensify at the one:twenty-five mark with the addition of a slow, fuzzed out, industrial heartbeat - as if to remind listeners that this is not your grandmother's top forty new page musicYou might be interested to know that Silentaria's Rixa White wears a white mask - "One mask to hide them all" (check the autobiography on this website) - and while this is effective at giving him a mysterious air (possibly making this music and philosophy seem more fascinating than it is) does it have the intended effect of wiping away the listener's preconceived notions for judgments? Well, yes and no - "yes" because we can't judge him for what the looks like if we can't see this face - "no" because less high-minded people will judge him for the very fact that they can't see this face - and invite the inevitable comparisons to other famous mask wearers such as Zorro, The Phantom of the Oprah, Jason in the FRIDAY THE thirteenTH movies, and maybe even Tom Cruise's character in VANILLA SKY. and perhaps that's fitting after all for a composer who attempts to express in musical form WHAT'S REAL? - it's a bit of a heroic gesture, and needs a strong character for the task. Mask for no mask, with such a deep idea explored through distinctive electronic tracks this intense and varied, WHAT'S REAL? deserves a large and devoted audience. Sincerely,Constant Listener

reviewText: Clutch has been around for over twenty years churning out album after album of top shelf rock. One bad routing can cause a lot of damage to any band's reputation, but that's something Clutch will never have to worry about. This band is so consistent, coming out of the blocks rocking on the title track a dynamic, vocally bombastic, full blooded banger due to Neil Fallon's characteristic intensity. The next cuts, "Terminal Velocity" and "Mister Freedom" continue the flow matching the opener step for step. The band has stated that "Earth Rocker will be a more harder and straight forward rocking album." I believe they nailed it. On and on it goes, with every passing track the realization is that there in't going to be a decline in quality, and that they may have produced an album that ranks up there comfortably with the best of their career. Tim Sult is probably better than most band's top basemen on this worst day and JP Gaster's rock drumming makes it look easy, but honorable mention goes to Neil Fallon as usual, for this "mixture of demented preacher speaking in tongues mixed with no frills blue collar rocker that sets them apart from the competition." The man has buckets of personality which overflow into the lyrics and the music. I read. "Earth Rocker is a rollicking heavy rock ride that showcases Clutch at the top of their game once again. With their 'no-filler, all-killer' logic and a fan-pleasing alteration in style, the outfit have churned out one of the their most widely appealing efforts thus far, not to mention a staple release for salt-rockers in two thousand and thirteen."The blues cuts and influences are not missing altogether, "D. C. Sound Attack!" is the song that has some of the most obvious blues influences. All the itunes are catchy and there is tons of energy happening there. Yeah, like Clutch is going to be laid back, LOL. So crank it up and blow out your speakers, as Dan Maines quotes. "I think this record comes closer to really capturing that energy of Clutch live. It's a very balanced album. There's no B-side material. It's an album of A-sides. That sounds pretty bold and confident, but that's the way we feel about Earth Rocker."I can't wait to receive my copy to listen to the total album rather than the snippets and you tube videos that are out there. So saddle up and ride this one still the horse packs it in as this rocker is going to wear you down.
summary: Clutch are still proving that nobody does it better....
